SECTION 751 - TRAFFIC CONTROL SYSTEMS MAINTENANCE

##This section cross-references Section 163.

If Section 163 is relevant, it should be included in the specification.

If Section 163 is not included in the specification, all references to it should be struck out, ensuring that the remaining text is still coherent:

This section covers maintenance of traffic control systems and ancillary systems such as traffic signals, traffic control and warning devices, computer cabins, multiplexers, termination huts, trip information signs, freeway condition signs, ramp metering and ramp control signs, variable message signs, help telephones, fibre optic network, and closed circuit television.

PART I - CONTRACT SPECIFIC MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS

PART 751.A - GENERAL

751.A01 GENERAL

This specification details requirements and standards of performance for the maintenance of traffic control system assets under the maintenance responsibility of the Roads Corporation of the State of Victoria (VicRoads).

This specification includes requirements for routine and non-routine maintenance activities, fault rectification and reporting to achieve the outcomes specified for all traffic control system assets.

All works shall be part of the Contract lump sum and the Contractor shall supply all materials, plant and testing equipment required under the Contract. All materials and works shall meet the requirements of the relevant VicRoads standards and specifications.

751.A02 SCOPE OF WORKS

(a) The Contractor shall inspect, maintain and report on each traffic control system asset to the specified requirements and for the specified functional requirements as part of the Contract lump sum. The Superintendent reserves the right to add to or delete from the number of devices included under the Contract.

(b) The Contractor shall provide a Non-Routine Attendance response capability to assist with faults and incidents on the road network.

(c) Maintenance Strategy

The Contractor shall implement an appropriate maintenance strategy that shall incorporate inspections, programming of work activities, for both pro-active and reactive nature to:

(i) ensure public safety;

(ii) minimise the rate of deterioration of the infrastructure;

(iii) sustain the functional requirements of each asset feature; and

(iv) recognise and respond to the requirements of road users.


751.A03 DEFINITIONS

The following definitions shall apply:

'A' and 'B' Ends

The 'A' end is the origin of the telecommunication line (i.e. the regional computer). The 'B' end is at the end facility of the telecommunications line (i.e. at the controller).

Advisory and Warning Devices

Devices used to provide advice or warning to drivers. They may comprise flashing lights, static or dynamic signs and detection systems.

AC

Alternating Current

Access point

Device that allows wireless communication devices to connect to a network.

After Hours

00:00 to 07:59 and 17:01 to 00:00 hours, Monday to Friday, and all day Saturdays, Sundays and Public Holidays.

Ante room

Part of a Regional Computer Cabin where communication interface, telephone, toilet and washbasin (where fitted) are located.

Aspect

A single optical system (circular, arrow or symbolic) on a signal face capable of being illuminated at a given time. Red, yellow, green and white aspects are used for vehicle movements.

BO

Black out

Building Warranty (BW)

Asset site under construction/remodel, and having a current construction and workmanship warranty for a specified duration or until completion/handover of the works.

Butt set (Buttinski)

Device used for the interrogation and programming of the telephone line.

CCTV

VicRoads Closed Circuit Television system for monitoring incidents and traffic flow. Includes cameras, poles, cabinets, transmission medium and transmission equipment.

CET

Cellular Emergency Telephone

CK

Checksum error

Computer Alarm

An automatically generated alarm that is displayed in SCATS.

Computer Room

Part of a Regional Computer Cabin where the logbooks, computer(s), air conditioner, modem (rack and cards), power supply and other items are located.

Concentrator

Equipment used to receive video and/or control signals from a number of sources and onward transmits as a multiplexed signal.

Controller

Electromechanical or electronic system for controlling the operation of traffic signals and other traffic devices.

Controller Cabinet

Approved housing for a controller, control relays, auxiliary equipment, terminal strips, sockets, flasher units, wiring, etc. May include vehicle detectors and linking equipment and a Telstra hatch isolation unit.

Critical Fault

A fault/event which requires immediate attendance outside predefined rectification times.

DA

Detector alarm

Dangerous Graffiti

Graffiti that is considered offensive (i.e. political, religious or racial nature), affects the operation of road signs or traffic signals, creates a distraction to drivers or affects lighting in underpasses.


DB Level

The decibel level measured on the telecom line.

DC

Direct Current

Decal

Adhesive label which may include site number and the VicRoads phone number for faults.

Decoder Board

An electronic circuit board that decodes the manchester control code and drives individual control outputs.

Detector Loop

In ground wiring configuration (including lead-in wires or tails) for the purpose of detection and/or counting of vehicle movements.

Display

A device which provides information to road users in a visual form.

Distribution Hut

A building used to house, as required, computer, communication and associated infrastructure to provide connection points and transfer equipment for other systems.

DZT

Serial Communication Port Test

EMP

Environment Monitoring Panel

Escalated Faults

Faults that may be notified to the Contractor for rectification, at any time on any day. The Contractor shall action Escalated faults in accordance with the Superintendents directions.

ESLS

Electronic Speed Limit Signs. Speed signs installed to manage vehicle speeds in areas defined as school zones and/or Shopping Centre Speed Zones.

EVP

Emergency Vehicle Pre-emption

EWP

Elevated Work Platform

Fault Notification

The action through a Contractor becomes aware of a fault.

Fault Number

A unique identification number allocated by VicRoads to a fault.

Feeder

Cable that connects loop tails with a designated traffic device unit.

Field Report

Technician's documentation on aspects of work conducted at a site.

Flashing Pedestrian Crossings

Flashing yellow traffic signals (Zebra Crossings) at or between intersections.

Foundation

Concrete base, including all conduits and bends, rag bolt assemblies and reinforcement cages, used to support traffic signal pedestals, traffic signal controllers or other equipment.

Freeway Condition Sign

A sign displaying dynamic information indicating flow conditions usually located near the entrance to a freeway.

Freeway Data Station

Traffic data collection system comprising roadside cabinet containing microprocessor, detection and communication equipment, and detector loops or similar. May include a radio communication system and a solar power system.

Graffiti

Unauthorised marking of VicRoads assets; includes bill posters or sprayed, written, scratched or slashed marks or symbols.

Handset and Cord

The hand held section used for communication and attached by cord to the pillar or housing.

Hazard

A condition or substance which has the potential to cause harm to the health and safety of persons.


Hazard Warning Sign

Static or electronic sign with flashers, displays or beacons to alert motorists of hazard (e.g. Intersection Ahead).

Height Warning Device

A device for warning drivers that their vehicle height may exceed a set limit. The devices usually incorporates a sensing beam, which when broken, activates a warning display.

Help Telephone

A roadside communication device for reporting emergencies or vehicle faults to TMC or CityLink Control Centre.

Ice Warning Station

Weather sensing warning station and associated advisory signs.

Illuminated sign

Device used for warning road users by displaying a message (e.g. Give Way To Trams).

Insert

Telephone assembly used in Telstra style pillar telephones.

Intersection Signals

Traffic signals located at road intersections operated by traffic signal controller.

IR

Invalid RAM

ISDN

Integrated System Digital Network. A high grade leased line used for transmission of video and data.

Lane Control Signals

Signals located along a designated route to indicate permitted direction of travel for individual lanes along the route.

LED

Light Emitting Diode

Lantern

Traffic control signal assembly, pedestrian control signal assembly, flashing signal assembly and internally illuminated sign assemblies, including all housings, target boards, visors, doors, lamp holders, reflectors, gaskets, lenses, straps, louvres, wiring, transformers, fixings and cables, etc.

Launch Amplifier

Electronic circuit which receives video at the site and converts it into a suitable form for transmission via fibre optic or other cable to the concentrator or to TMC.

LSU

Line Signalling Unit

Maintenance

Activities undertaken to ensure that the equipment remains in proper working condition. Includes routine maintenance, non routine maintenance and in addition to all other work specified, the following:

(a) repair and/or replacement of all defective, damaged or worn components or parts thereof to ensure the proper operation of the equipment;

(b) repair and/or adjustment of all connections, wiring and time settings required to establish accurate operation of the equipment;

(c) supply, installation and maintenance of temporary traffic control equipment whilst repairs are conducted on permanent equipment;

(d) routine inspection and servicing of all site hardware, controller and ancillary equipment.

Maintenance Group or Maintenance Area

A number of traffic devices grouped (geographically, type or system) for the purpose of tender and/or contract purposes.

Major Faults

Faults that may be notified to the Contractor, for rectification, at any time on any day.

Manchester Code Control

A digital code running at 31.5 kHz carrying coded control information.

MDF

Main Distribution Frame. The cabinet containing an assembly of strip mounted wiring modules on which are terminated the lead-in cables(s) and cross connection to VicRoads cabling.


MicroConnect Linking Control Module

Device used to interface SCATS with a traffic signal controller on a Dial-IP line.

MicroConnect Inline Modem

Device used to interface the MicroConnect Linking Control Module with PTF, PTF3 and Delta 3 signal controllers.

Multiplexer

A device that selects between a number of signal inputs.

Multiplex Cabinets for SCATS

(MUX Cabinets) - An on-street housing containing logbook, line isolation unit (LIU); modem cards and rack; Dataplex DPX 650 Multiplexer (communication transmission equipment); power board, Telstra NTU 9.6 kb/s Sync; sustained power supply; switch board; main distribution frame; LSU modem cards and other items.

NC

No Carrier signal detected on the communication line.

Network Switch

Network device that is used to connect segments of a LAN (local area network).

Non Routine Maintenance

The repair and/or replacement of equipment damaged or defective through any cause and shall require 24 hour, 7 days availability.

NTU

Network Termination Unit

Office Hours

0800 to 1700 hours, Monday to Friday, excluding Public Holidays.

Optic Fibre

Thin strand of optically pure glass, surrounded by Teflon coating.

Optic Fibre Cable

A number of strands of optic fibre.

OTDR

Optical Time Domain Reflectometry. A method of evaluating optical fibres based on detecting back-scattered (reflected) light, used to measure fibre attenuation, evaluate splice and connector joints and locate faults.

Other Faults

Faults that may be notified to the Contractor, for rectification, during office hours.

Out of order tape

Red and white plastic tape, approximately 50 mm wide, over printed with the words 'Out of Order'.

Pan/Tilt Head

Motorised camera base capable of moving in both horizontal (pan) and vertical (tilt) planes. The camera and lens enclosure is mounted on top of the pan/tilt head.

Pan/Tilt Head Relay Board

Equipment that converts pan/tilt head and speed control signals to motor drivers.

PC

Personal Computer

Pedestal

A post used primarily for the support of signal lantern(s) including mast arms, joint use poles and joint use mast arms. Posts maintained by other Authorities that are used to support traffic signal lanterns are not included in this definition.

Pedestrian Detector

Push button or other detection device used to place a call for pedestrian phase in order to actuate the pedestrian walk phases. It may or may not include audio tactile devices and call-record indicators.

Pedestrian Signals

Traffic signals generally located between intersections operated by a traffic signal controller, includes Pedestrian Operated Signals (POS).

Personality File

Information containing signal phasing, together with other data defining the operation of an intersection or loop allocation for freeway data stations.


Pillar

Housing used for termination of communication lines for freeway emergency telephones.

PSTN

Public Switched Telephone Network. A standard grade leased line used for transmission of voice, video or data.

Public Holidays

Days gazetted as 'Public Holidays' in accordance with the Victorian Public Service.

RAI

Road Asset Inventory. VicRoads database of site information and fault records.

Ramp Control Sign

A sign displaying information to traffic on a freeway entrance ramp.

RC

Ramp Control, system used to control traffic flow/access on a freeway entry.

Ramp Control Sign, Stand Alone

Ramp Control Sign directly driven from control room not via a traffic signal controller/ramp metering device.

RCD

Residual Current Device

Red Light Camera / Speed Camera

Camera, flash and detector loop configuration for infringement purposes.

Comprises mounting poles, underground cabling, camera and flash housings.

Regional Computer Cabin

Building used to house computer, communication and associated equipment used as part of the VicRoads traffic signal coordination system. Comprises Computer Room and Ante Room.

Registration / Pre-Qualification

A requirement for contractors to be approved to undertake works on traffic devices. Registration is required in a number of pre-qualification categories to undertake works on those categories of equipment.

Relay

Electromechanical or solid state assembly within a controller cabinet for the purpose of switching of electrical circuits.

Repeater

Radio modem/network device that is used to regenerate or replicate signals.


Routine Maintenance

Inspection and servicing of all onsite equipment including but not limited to:

(a) Burn Out Runs (not including bulk lamp changes);

(b) Routine Services;

(c) Periodic replacement of components.

RX Level

Receiving level measured in decibels.

SCATS

Sydney Coordinated Adaptive Traffic System.

Site Number

The unique identification number of the asset as provided by the Superintendent (e.g. Site Number 5881 - Midland Highway / Drummond Street intersection).

Slave Unit

Any modular unit used to control all displays on one gantry as being part of a lane control system.

Speed Zones Devices

Devices to vary the speed limit over a defined length of road, usually comprising variable speed limit signs, flashing lights and an operating mechanism.

ST

No 'handshake' between devices.

Support

Shall include all structural components, brackets, clamps, straps and parts thereof, used to support traffic signal equipment.


TMC

VicRoads Traffic Management Centre, which can be contacted 24 hours a day on:

Public line 13 11 70

Contractor line (03) 9855 7510

Facsimile 03 9854 2381

SMR (VicRoads system) 300

Traffic Device

A range of items of electrical/electronic equipment designed to provide advice, guidance or direction to road users or to assist in the control or monitoring of traffic, including traffic signals, lane control signals, variable speed signs, warning signs, height gauges, regional computer cabins, multiplexers, distribution huts, trip signs, freeway condition signs, ramp control signs, variable message signs, freeway data stations, roadside help telephones and CCTV equipment.

Traffic Signals

A traffic device comprising traffic signal lanterns and control equipment to provide direction to road users, and including intersection signals, pedestrian signals and pedestrian crossings.

Trip Information Sign

A dynamic sign displaying real time travel time and traffic flow information to road users on freeways.

TX Level

Transmitting level (measured in decibels).

Variable Message Sign (VMS)

A sign able to display a range of images by means of configuring a matrix of pixels.

VSLS

Variable Speed Limit System. System designed to operate dynamically with Electronic speed limit signs.

WD

Watchdog is a computer alarm generated by SCATS indicating a type of signal controller fault.

Wireless Sensor (Stud)

In ground sensor used as part of a wireless vehicle detector system for the purpose of detection and/or counting of vehicle movements.

751.A04 FUNCTIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF MAINTENANCE

The Contractor shall undertake maintenance in accordance with this specification to ensure the assets and devices are in a safe operating condition by the following:

Traffic Signals and Miscellaneous Control Warning Devices

• provide safe driving conditions;

• should have minimum display performance not less than 95% per site, but not less than 60% of displays of the same state per signal group;

• provide timely emergency response to minimise unsafe conditions and disruption caused by temporary failure of the asset or components;

• provide clear messages to motorists in day and night conditions;

• maintain structural integrity;

• undertake operational tests;

• test and maintain electronic and ancillary systems and additional hardware (all equipment connected to or driven by a traffic signal controller or a field processor, e.g. illuminated pavement markers or other displays).

Under this contract Traffic Signals are deemed to be but not limited to: intersection, pedestrian and flashing, ramp and round-about metering (includes all additional illuminated signs), fire wig-wag, fire, lane control systems, etc.

Miscellaneous Control Warning Devices include height gauges, test stations, speed advisory signs, other warning devices, etc.


Regional Computer Cabins and Distribution Huts

• provide timely emergency response to minimise unsafe conditions and disruption caused by temporary loss of use of the asset or components;

• maintain clean and hygienic conditions in and around the cabin;

• provide aesthetically sound appearance to external and internal areas;

• maintain all building hardware in sound operational condition;

• test and maintain all computer and electronic systems / hardware;

• undertake operational tests;

• ensure security system, air conditioning and other plant is operational and serviceable.

The mainframe computer system (PDP-11 or any future such hardware) within each SCATS Regional Computer Cabin is not included in the works.

Multiplexer Cabinets

• provide timely emergency response to minimise unsafe conditions and disruption caused by temporary failure of the asset or components;

• test and maintain all electronic systems / hardware;

• undertake operational tests;

• ensure structural integrity.

Trip Information Signs, Freeway Condition Signs, Stand Alone Ramp Control Signs, Variable Message Signs

• provide clear messages to motorists in day and night conditions;

• maintain structural integrity;

• test and maintain all electronic systems / hardware;

• undertake operational tests.

Help Phones

• provide timely emergency response to minimise unsafe conditions and disruption caused by temporary failure of the asset or components;

• maintain in clean and hygienic condition;

• maintain structural integrity;

• test and maintain all electronic systems / hardware;

• undertake operational tests;

• check and ensure safe and clear access.

Freeway Data Stations:

• provide timely emergency response to minimise unsafe conditions and disruption caused by temporary failure of the asset or components;

• maintain structural integrity;

• test and maintain all electronic systems / hardware;

• undertake operational tests.

Closed Circuit Television

• provide timely emergency response to minimise unsafe conditions and disruption caused by temporary failure of the asset or components;

• ensure clear pictures to users in day and night conditions;

• maintain structural integrity;

• test and maintain all electronic systems / hardware;

• undertake operational tests.


751.A05 DESCRIPTION OF DEVICES/ASSETS

The Contractor shall maintain all Traffic Signal and Miscellaneous Traffic Control and Warning Devices inclusive of ancillary equipment but not limited to:

• lanterns and displays;

• communication modems;

• supply and program EPROM or PCMCIA card, maintenance purposes only (personality file supplied by VicRoads);

• pedestals including footings, outreaches where fitted, concrete surrounds and paved/slab bases, mounting brackets, finial caps, termination assemblies, termination assembly housings where fitted, fixings and paint work;

• push-buttons including driver units, indicator lamps and audio tactile devices; associated button operation advice labels/decals mounted on pedestal;

• detection system including loops, cable coils, pavement slot, slot seals, conduit, coil housings where fitted, labels and connections;

• controllers/field processors including housing, software and firmware; labels/decals, locks, hinges, internal components, paved / slab bases and footings;

• advanced flashing signals including signs, support posts, terminations, housings, all internal components, concrete surrounds and paved/slab bases and footings;

• pits, surrounds and lids, conduit, wiring, cable, cable route markers and terminations;

• point of supply equipment (power and communication) including terminations, distribution boards and meter boxes.

The Contractor shall maintain all Regional Computer Cabins and Distribution Huts including but not limited:

• internal co-ordination and communications equipment;

• central monitoring systems including monitors and communications equipment, uninterrupted power supply units, line status of both 'A' and 'B' ends;

• key entry devices (electronic and mechanical security systems), labels/decals, locks, hinges;

• pits, pit lids, conduit, wiring, cable, cable route markers and terminations;

• wiring and communication distribution frames and units;

• firmware and software;

• internal building lighting and external security lighting;

• telephones, plumbing, lighting, water provisions, air conditioning, environmental systems or other support systems;

• interior and exterior walls, ceilings and roof;

• landscaping (mowing grass and cleaning of surrounding areas);

• point of supply equipment (power and communication) including terminations, distribution boards and meter boxes.


The Contractor shall maintain all Multiplexer equipment including but not limited to:

• footings, foundation bolts, bases and fixings;

• uninterrupted power supply units;

• cabinets (exterior and interior), labels/decals, locks, hinges, including all internal components;

• multiplexing equipment display (modems/RX/ TX communications, LED indicators);

• cable pits, access cover and frames, conduit, wiring, cable, cable route markers and terminations;

• associated software and firmware;

• point of supply equipment (power and communication) including terminations, distribution boards and meter boxes.

The Contractor shall maintain all Trip Information Signs, stand alone Ramp Control Signs, Freeway Condition Signs, and Variable Message Signs equipment including but not limited to:

• message displays including housings, control equipment and fixings;

• foundations and bolts;

• access facilities, ladders, handrails and platforms;

• monitoring and communications cabinets including all internal components, footings and detection facilities;

• pits, conduits, cables, cable route markers and terminations;

• communications interface equipment;

• handles, labels/decals, locks and hinges;

• support systems such as environment control systems;

• associated software and firmware;

• point of supply equipment (power and communication) including terminations, distribution boards and meter boxes.

The Contractor shall maintain all Hazard Warning Sign, Illuminated and Speed Advisory Sign, and Ice Warning Station and Sign equipment including but not limited to:

• message displays and lanterns including housings, control equipment, fixings, detection and monitoring facilities;

• handles, labels/decals, locks, hinges;

• foundation and bolts;

• access facilities, ladders, handrails;

• pits, conduit, wiring, cable, cable route markers and terminations;

• remote monitoring and communications interface equipment including communication termination boxes;

• support systems such as environment control systems;

• associated software and firmware;

• point of supply equipment including terminations, distribution boards, meter boxes, solar panel system, battery terminals and batteries.


The Contractor shall maintain all Freeway Data Stations equipment including but not limited to:

• foundation and bolts;

• columns or other support structures including outreaches, solar panel systems, battery terminals, radio equipment and antennas;

• controller cabinets (exterior and interior), labels/decals, locks, hinges, including all internal components;

• RX/ TX communications and LED indicators;

• detection system and associated functional indicators;

• detection loops including cable coils, pavement slot, slot seals, conduit, coil housings where fitted, labels and connections, wireless sensors;

• cable/detector pits, conduits, wiring, cables, cable route markers and terminations;

• remote monitoring and control equipment, including receivers, power supplies and all other terminals, modems, terminal adapters, mounting racks and cabling;

• associated software and firmware;

• point of supply equipment including terminations, meter boxes, batteries, solar panels;

• access points, repeaters, IP radio modems, antennas, power supplies and power injectors (for wireless detector systems).

The Contractor shall maintain all Help Telephone equipment including but not limited to:

• help telephones including posts, housings, hinges and catches, handsets, footings and fixings associated labels/decals;

• GSM phone systems;

• solar panels systems and batteries;

• pits, pit covers, conduits, cables, cable route markers and terminations;

• communications pillar;

• standing areas (concrete pad and any path leading to help phones);

• point of supply equipment where fitted.

The Contractor shall maintain all Closed Circuit Television equipment including but not limited:

• columns or other support structures including outreaches, footings, foundation bolts, cages, fixings and rise and lowering systems;

• cameras including camera housings, pan/tilt mechanisms, rotors, gears and motors;

• cabinets, labels/decals, locks, hinges, including all internal components and footings;

• pits, conduit, wiring, cable, cable route markers and terminations;

• remote monitoring and control equipment, transmission infrastructure, including fibre optic systems, power supplies, modems, terminal adapters, and cabling, multiplexers and decoders, video and data transceivers;

• associated software and firmware;

• point of supply equipment (power and communication) including terminations, distribution boards and batteries.

The Contractor shall maintain Fibre Optic Network equipment including but not limited:

• fibre optic cables, pits, cable route markers, underground enclosures termination boxes, pigtails, patch cords, etc;

• network switches, patch panels, patch cords, power supplies, modems, multiplexers, etc.

FOR ALL ABOVE MENTIONED ASSETS, THE CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE TO UPDATE THE AS‑CONSTRUCTED DRAWINGS IF ANY CHANGES OCCUR DUE TO ALL MAINTENANCE AND UPGRADE WORKS UNDERTAKEN BY THE CONTRACTOR.


751.A06 CONTRACTOR RESOURCES

Maintenance of the assets specified requires routine and non-routine maintenance attendance, twenty-four hours per day, seven days per week. The service required is of a technical nature, including all civil, electrical and electronic repairs and/or replacement activities necessary to return existing and future assets specified under this contract to full working order.

All field personnel engaged on VicRoads' maintenance activities shall be appropriately licensed to meet the requirements of all relevant state and federal authorities and agencies (including Energy Safe Victoria and the Australian Communication Authority). All personnel employed or engaged to undertake works under this Contract shall be trained for safe and efficient execution of the necessary works.

The Contractor shall, at all times through the contract period, maintain the necessary complement of accredited staff and resources required to meet contractor registration requirements. The Contractor shall notify the Superintendent of changes to the submitted registration details within fourteen (14) days of such changes occurring.

The Contractor shall maintain an up to date list of staff, per Schedule 17 - Management/Supervisory Personnel, who undertake works under this Contract. The Contractor shall notify the Superintendent of changes to the details within fourteen (14) days of such changes occurring. The Contractor shall provide this list to the Superintendent within 24 hours of request.

The Contractor shall maintain at his premises or on call at all times adequate supporting personnel and the necessary facilities to affect any type of repair and shall provide all diagnostic and support equipment, manuals, documentation and drawings necessary for maintenance.

The Contractor shall ensure that the Superintendent is able to contact the company's nominated supervisor or his representative during any office hours period and must be able to directly contact service personnel on duty after hours.

For the purpose of receiving fault reports, providing feedback and coordinating follow-up works, the Contractor shall provide:

(a) an operational office/workshop environment during nominated office hour periods;

(b) an operational telephone service during after hours periods.

The contractor shall as part of the Contract lump sum, provide a sufficient number of generators on stand-by 24 hours a day with capacity to provide temporary power supply to any traffic control system included in the Contract. The Contractor shall ensure that it has access to additional generators, 24 hours a day, if required. The Contractor shall ensure that it has access to a crane truck and travel tower 24 hours a day.

The Contractor shall, at all times through the Contract period, supply and maintain all necessary stock of spare parts in order to meet the Contract requirements.


751.A07 RELEVANT SPECIFICATIONS AND STANDARDS

Works shall be in accordance with but not limited to the following relevant Australian Standards and VicRoads specifications:

• VicRoads, Safety Requirements for Traffic Devices Works on Traffic Signals and on Road Electrical and Communication Devices (refer Attachment A);

• AS 3000 Electrical Installations - Buildings, Structures and Premises (SAA Wiring Rules);

• AS 1742 Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices;

• AS 2144 Traffic Signal Lanterns;

• AS 2353 Pedestrian Push-button Assemblies;

• AS 1275 Metric Screw Threads for Fasteners;

• VicRoads, ITS Group: Standard Drawings and Specifications;

• Energy Safe Victoria publications and safety alerts;

• Code of Practice for Safe Electrical Work, Low Voltage Electrical Installations;

• Australian Communications Authority document 'Customer Premises Cabling Manual'.

In the absence of relevant requirements within these or other VicRoads specifications, published Australian Standards shall apply.

751.A08 THIRD PARTY SERVICES

It shall be the responsibility of the Contractor to ascertain the presence, location and ownership of any third party services in the vicinity of the assets under their responsibility and to ensure that the relevant Authority is notified of works which may affect such services.

Before conducting any work in the vicinity of others assets/properties, the Contractor shall make such arrangements for properly removing or protecting these assets/properties for the duration of works. Any damages to such services shall be immediately reported to the owner of the service and to the Superintendent and shall be repaired by the Contractor to the satisfaction of the owners of the service.

Where malfunctions involve equipment under the control of others, the Contractor shall advise the Superintendent of the situation and to be available for such site meetings as may be necessary to rectify the fault. The Superintendent shall be kept informed of all actions undertaken.

751.A09 MANUFACTURER/SUPPLIER WARRANTY AND CAUSES

It is the Contractors responsibility to rectify a fault or malfunction which involves any equipment covered under current warranty provisions. Where persons other than the nominated Contractor are engaged by VicRoads to conduct such repairs VicRoads shall advise the Contractor of the situation as soon as practical.

Where a potentially hazardous situation exists and is related to warranty or third party causes, the Contractor will at the discretion of the Superintendent, remove such hazard by temporary repair, interim action or complete works to remove the hazard and ensure that the systems and assets are operating normally.

751.A10 BUILDING WARRANTY

Where the Superintendent advises the Contractor that a site within a maintenance group is to fall under building warranty due to a remodel or similar, the Contractor shall be relieved of all maintenance responsibilities with the exception of Burn Out Runs as specified in Part H, Routine Maintenance Activities in accordance with the works program.


751.A11 CONTRACTOR WARRANTY

For all works conducted by the Contractor, the Contractor shall provide a ninety (90) day warranty period on all workmanship associated with such work.

The rectification of any failure caused by reason of poor workmanship on the part of the Contractor shall be rectified by the Contractor at no additional cost to VicRoads.

751.A12 OPERATING STATUS CHANGES

Where it is necessary to change the operational status of any asset or device, for example:

• switching of signals to flash, or returning flashing signals to operational mode;

• changing the display of Trip Information Signs, Freeway Condition Signs, Variable Speed Signs, or similar devices from a display other than correct;

• activating the display of Ramp Control Signs, Over Height Warning Devices, Variable Speed Displays or similar devices to display;

the Contractor shall immediately advise TMC of the change of status, record the date and times of such changes on the Maintenance Record Card, and record the date and times of such changes on the Routine Service Report or Non-Routine Attendance Report.

The Contractor shall not unnecessarily switch any asset or device from normal operational mode and shall make all best endeavours to minimise the time the asset or device is not in normal operational mode.

751.A13 PROVIDING MINIMUM DISPLAY

Whilst working on traffic signals or other electrical/electronic display that are operating, the Contractor shall ensure that at least 60% of lanterns/displays on each signal group are operational.

751.A14 DAMAGED, OBSELETE OR REDUNDANT EQUIPMENT

All damaged, defective or redundant equipment or component parts from sites maintained under the contract are to be promptly removed from the work site and, except for any controller or controller component, disposed of by the Contractor. The Contractor shall, for any controller or controller component, obtain the Superintendent's approval before disposal of same. The Contractor shall store and deliver as per agreed time, controller or controller components to a nominated location or as otherwise directed by the Superintendent.

751.A15 TIME/DATE ADJUSTMENTS

The Contractor shall, where on-site equipment requires time/date adjustments, undertake these adjustments promptly. The Contractor shall ascertain the sites requiring time/date adjustments and supply to the Superintendent in the following working day a list, detailing all changes made.

751.A16 COMMUNICATIONS AND OTHER SERVICE PROVIDER FAULTS

The Contractor shall undertake all necessary liaisons with the Service Provider and co-ordinate the rectification of such faults within the time frame specified. The Contractor shall report back to the Superintendent as required until the fault is rectified.

This may include but is not limited to the following service authorities:

• Telstra, Optus or other communications providers;

• public transport authorities;

• power supply authorities;

• gas supply authorities;

• water supply authorities.


751.A17 VICROADS SECURITY SYSTEM

The Contractor shall be responsible for the re-programming of the electronic security system 'Smart Lock - Tag Readers' located on the external walls at each SCATS Regional Computer Cabin and Distribution Hut. On the Superintendent's request the Contractor shall download lock access memory and present data in an approved format.

VicRoads will provide 'Electronic Tags' and 'Mechanical Bi-Lock Keys' to the Contractor to gain access to undertake the specified works at VicRoads SCATS Regional Computer Cabin and Distribution Huts.

Upon issue of any 'Electronic Tags' or 'Mechanical Bi-Lock Keys', the recipient shall complete a VicRoads 'Registration Form' and an acknowledgment signature(s) will be required by both the recipient and the company for issue of the tag(s) and key(s).

The quantity and availability of 'Electronic Tags' and 'Mechanical Bi-Lock Keys' during the contract period shall be at the discretion of the Superintendent.

The Contractor shall return 'Electronic Tags' and 'Mechanical Bi-Lock Keys' to VicRoads at the end of the Contract period, upon termination of the Contract or upon request by the Superintendent.

For the purpose of maintenance, the Contractor shall provide all locks in accordance with VicRoads Security Locking System 'B9‑67 - Bi‑Lock Key System. A description of VicRoads Bi‑Lock Security Locking System is included in Attachment B.

751.A18 COMMISSIONING AND CONNECTION OF COMMUNICATION LINE

The contractors shall ensure all communication lines/mediums are in working order, and if reported to be faulty, shall investigate, repair and report outcome to the Superintendent.

If a new communication line is required to replace the existing communication line, the contractor shall arrange the connection.

Connection, testing and commissioning of the SCATS communications line shall be carried out in accordance with VicRoads procedure attached in Attachment C.

751.A19 LAMPS

All lamps used for maintenance shall conform with the relevant Australian Standards, VicRoads specifications and the following requirements:

Incandescent lamps

(a) 200 mm vehicle lanterns and pedestrian lanterns - 240 volt, 65‑70 watt incandescent lamps;

(b) 300 mm vehicle lanterns - 240 volt, 100 watt incandescent lamps.

Quartz-halogen lamps

(a) 200 mm and 300 mm vehicle lanterns and pedestrian lanterns - 12 volt 50 watt bi‑pin quartz-halogen lamps;

(b) fibre-optic display signs, Trip Information signs, Ramp Control signs, Freeway Condition signs - 10 volt, 50 watt Dichroic Reflector quartz-halogen lamps.

LED lanterns

(a) Each aspect shall conform to the requirements for chromaticity and photometric performance of AS 2144:2002;

(b) the LED lanterns must be VicRoads type approved products.


751.A20 FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH SPECIFIED REQUIREMENTS AND SCHEDULE OF WORKS

Where the Contractor fails to:

(a) undertake and complete works in accordance with the specified requirements or standards; or

(b) undertake and complete works in accordance with the works schedule or works program; or

(c) undertake and complete works as directed by the Superintendent;

(d) provide or arrange plant or equipment as specified in the Contract;

(e) record or provide the information specified in the Contract.

The Superintendent will, at his discretion either:

• deduct from the monthly claim and Contract Sum, the value of the uncompleted works, as determined by the Superintendent using the rates tendered in Schedule 2;

• utilise other contractors/resources to carry out these works with the actual cost of doing so (including VicRoads administration) being deducted from the Contractor's monthly payment and Contract Sum; or

• deduct 10% of the monthly claim amount for the assets affected in accordance with the rate(s) tendered in Schedule 2.

Where such rates in Schedule 2 are not considered appropriate or are not, in the assessment of the Superintendent, representative of the value, the Superintendent will determine the value. Where, in the opinion of the Superintendent, the Contractor fails to undertake works in accordance with Section 751.H01, Routine Maintenance Schedule, the Superintendent may make a pro-rata deduction to the tendered rate for maintenance based on the period of non-conformance with the maintenance schedule.

Where, in the opinion of the Superintendent, the Contractor has not actioned a fault in accordance with the specified requirements for fault rectification, or advising/reporting Non‑Routine Attendance Non‑Conformance, the Superintendent may use other contractors/resources to carry out these works. The cost of using other contractors/resources and administrative charges shall be borne by the Contractor.

Where, in the opinion of the Superintendent, the Contractor has failed to adequately undertake works or to adequately record and provide information to the specified standards or requirements, the Superintendent may use other contractors/resources to carry out these works or to ascertain and provide the information. The cost of using other contractors/resources and administrative charges shall be borne by the Contractor.

Where the same fault or malfunction has occurred on three (3) occasions within a thirty (30) day period or where, in the opinion of the Superintendent, the Contractor has failed to adequately identify and rectify the fault, the Superintendent may use other contractors/resources for investigation and/or rectification of a fault. The cost of using other contractors/resources and administrative charges shall be borne by the Contractor.

751.A21 CERTIFICATE OF ELECTRICAL SAFETY

All electrical works undertaken as part of the Contract shall be covered by a Certificate of Electrical safety in accordance with the requirements of Energy Safe Victoria. The Certificate(s) and any associated documents shall be retained by the Contractor in an auditable (site specific) environment and shall be made available to the Superintendent upon request.

A colour scan of the original certificate shall be supplied to VicRoads on the following working day, with file name, Site Number and Job Number.


PART 751.B - ROUTINE MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS

751.B01 ROUTINE MAINTENANCE - GENERAL

Routine maintenance shall comprise, but is not limited to, the inspection and servicing of all assets/hardware as specified in Part 751.H. The Contractor shall carry out Routine Maintenance in accordance with the specified schedule in Section 751.H01.

Any fault or defect detected during such inspections shall be recorded and rectified in accordance with the requirements of this specification.

The Contractor shall record all site attendances on the Maintenance Record Card.

751.B02 TRAFFIC SIGNALS AND MISCELLANEOUS CONTROL AND WARNING DEVICES

(a) Routine Maintenance

In addition to any other works specified, routine maintenance shall comprise the inspection and servicing of all on site equipment and shall include:

● Routine Service

● Burn Out Runs

(i) Routine Services

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Traffic Signal site and each Miscellaneous Control and Warning Device every six (6) months in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Part H, Routine Maintenance Activities, Traffic Signals and Miscellaneous Control and Warning Devices, Routine Service.

(ii) Burn Out Runs

The Contractor shall undertake a Burn Out Run for each site at a minimum of every 30 days in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H04.

All faulty, obscured or miss-aligned displays shall be rectified immediately except where the display is mounted at a height of 4.5 m or greater, in which case rectification shall be completed within 120 hours.

All missing or damaged pedestrian visors, 200 mm or 300 mm lantern visors, louvres or target boards shall be rectified within 48 hours of being observed during the Burn Out Run except where the display is mounted at a height of 4.5 m or greater, in which case rectification shall be completed within 168 hours.

(b) Display Performance

Where, for the Display Performance (see Clause 751.E08) the following occurs:

(i) two (2) % or more quartz halogen globes per Traffic Signal Maintenance Group under contract have been replaced per month; or

(ii) two (2) % or more incandescent globes per Traffic Signal Maintenance Group under contract have been replaced per month; or

(iii) two (2) % or more LED aspects per Traffic Signal Maintenance Group under contract have been replaced per month; or

(iv) two (2) % or more of the sum of quartz halogen globes and incandescent globes per Traffic Signal Maintenance Group under contract have been replaced per month;

the Contractor shall increase the frequency of burn out runs to ensure all of the above conditions are reduced below 2 % per burn out run. Where the Contractor can demonstrate over two consecutive months that the number of globes not working is less than 2%, the inspection frequency may be reduced to that initially specified with the agreement of the Superintendent.


Where the Contractor increases the frequency of burn out runs it shall be for the entire network. A frequency increase for part of the network shall not be permitted.

Further to Clause 751.H02, Program and Progress - Whole of Works, and Clause 751.H03, Program and Progress - Daily Confirmation, the Contractor shall include the increased frequency of burn out runs in the Whole of Works Program and the Daily Confirmations.

(c) PTF RAM Backup Battery

PTF RAM backup batteries are to be replaced every 12 months within 28 days after commencing the contract.

751.B03 REGIONAL COMPUTER CABINS

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each SCATS Regional Computer every calendar month in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H05.

Works may be carried out at any time of the day, however due to their locations; access to some SCATS Regional Computer Cabins may in some circumstances be restricted to office hours.

Any additional equipment within a regional computer cabin added during the course of the Contract shall be maintained by the Contractor as part of the lump sum.

751.B04 MULTIPLEXERS AND DISTRIBUTION HUTS

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Multiplexer Cabinet and each Distribution Hut every six (6) months in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01, 751.H06 and 751.H07.

Works may be carried out at any time of the day, however due to their locations, access to some SCATS Multiplexer Cabinets and Distribution Huts may in some circumstances be restricted to office hours.

751.B05 TRIP INFORMATION SIGNS

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Trip Information sign every six (6) months in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H08, Routine Maintenance Activities, Trip Information Signs, Routine Service.

751.B06 STAND ALONE RAMP CONTROL SIGNS AND FREEWAY CONDITION SIGNS

(a) General

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Freeway Condition Sign and each Stand Alone Ramp Control Sign every six (6) months in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H09.

(b) On-Site Testing

Whenever the display of a ramp control sign or freeway condition sign is activated or changed for testing and/or maintenance purposes, the Contractor shall obscure the sign so it is not visible to traffic.

The method of obscuring the sign shall be submitted to the Superintendent for review within four (4) weeks of award of contract.


751.B07 VARIABLE MESSAGE SIGNS

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Variable Message Sign every six (6) months in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H10.

751.B08 FREEWAY DATA STATIONS

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Incident Detection site every six (6) months.

Routine Services shall be in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H11.

The Contractor shall maintain Freeway Data Stations in accordance with the following requirements, copies of which are provided in Attachment D:

(a) VicRoads Freeway Data Stations Detection Stations - System Checks (limited);

(b) Solar Power System for VicRoads Freeway Data Stations;

(c) Radio Communication System for VicRoads Freeway Data Stations.

751.B09 HELP PHONES

(a) General

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Help Telephone every eight (8) weeks. Routine Services shall be in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H12.

(b) Description of Current Help Phone Types

PLESSEY Post mounted box with telephone assembly and handset. Blue housing with spring loaded door. Handset, Telephone assembly and circuit board. Post and sleeve.

ANSA MK 1 and 3 Post mounted box with telephone assembly and handset. Blue housing with spring loaded door. Handset, Telephone assembly and circuit board. Post, sleeve and/or base. PAD card (autodial only). Mounting bracket.

TELSTRA MK 1 * Two (2) metre tall Blue/Silver pillar with red fibreglass insert (contains handset and telephone circuitry). Electronic components are mounted on the back of the insert together with the connection for the handset. PAD card (autodial only) and 603 series telephone modified for Help Phone use.

TELSTRA MK 2 * Two (2) metre tall Blue/Silver pillar with red fibreglass insert (contains handset and telephone circuitry). Electronic components are mounted on the back of the insert together with the connection for the handset. PAD card (autodial only) and 603 series telephone modified for Help Phone use. Telephone ringer module for Mk 2 telephone.

CET * Two (2) metre tall Blue/Silver pillar with white insert (contains handset). Solar power panel and aerial mounted on top of pillar. Cellular unit in the bottom.

CLEARSONICS WayPhone. Pedestal WayPhones are blue pillar type phones with hands-free operation (no handset) and cable free cellular communications. A solar option may be implemented.

NOTE * The above handset is not a field replaceable item due to the difficulty of replacement and the incompatibility of various types.


(c) Method of Cabling Help Phones

Currently there are three cabling methods used to connect the Help Phone to VicRoads TMC as follows:

(i) an exchange line from the communications provider;

(ii) a connection via VicRoads cable running along the carriageway to a VicRoads sub-centre/PABX;

(iii) an exchange line from the communications provider to a VicRoads termination pillar. Telstra provide an Easycall Delayed Hot Line for direct connection. In this case the dialling sequence is programmed into the Telstra exchange and is initiated automatically when the handset is picked up.

751.B10 CLOSED CIRCUIT TELEVISION

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each CCTV camera installation every six (6) months.

Routine Services shall be in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H13.

751.B11 ICE DETECTION AND WARNING DEVICES

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Ice Detection Station and Warning Sign every twelve (12) months in April. Routine Services shall be in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H14.

751.B12 HAZARD WARNING SIGNS

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Hazard Warning Sign every six (6) months. Routine Services shall be in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H15.

751.B13 ILLUMINATED AND SPEED ADVISORY SIGNS

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for each Illuminated and Speed Advisory Sign every six (6) months. Routine Services shall be in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H16.

751.B14 FIBRE OPTIC NETWORK

The Contractor shall undertake a Routine Service for VicRoads owned fibre optic network every six (6) months. Routine Services shall be in accordance with the schedule, activities and performance levels detailed in Parts 751.H01 and 751.H162.


PART 751.C - NON ROUTINE MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS

751.C01 FAULT NOTIFICATION

The Contractor may become aware of a fault in a number of ways, including but not limited to:

• notification by TMC;

• notification by the Superintendent;

• observation by the Contractor (fault needs to be reported to VicRoads in order to be recorded in RAI).

Notification of faults by the Superintendent or TMC will be in accordance with the 'Fault Call-Out Procedure', Attachment E.

Notification to the Contractor shall be deemed to have occurred once the fault has been relayed to the Contractor's nominated fault receiving service, whether this is a message bank, call answering service, office representative or other.

'Other' faults will be notified to the Contractor at any time on any day but only actioned during office hours.

'Major' faults will be notified to the Contractor at any time on any day and they shall be actioned in accordance with the specified requirements.

'Escalated' fault is an initial fault raised to an increased response level. The fault is assessed by the Superintendent and based on the severity of the consequence which may be a result of the fault. 'Escalated' faults will be notified to the Contractor at any time on any day and the Contractor shall act on these in accordance with the Superintendent's direction.

Faults will be defined as 'Escalated', 'Major' or 'Other' based on the information available. The Contractor will not be entitled to additional costs for any of the following:

• fault attendances escalated from 'Other' to 'Major';

• any fault attendance being the result of no fault found for the initial call-out.

'Critical' Faults are faults outside predefined rectification times and they will be notified to the Contractor at any time on any day and the Contractor shall act on these in accordance with the Superintendent's direction. 'Critical' faults are to be paid outside the lump sum with the exception of subsequent attendances for the same fault.

The Contractor shall provide feedback information in accordance with the requirements of the 'Fault Call-Out Procedure' and this specification.

751.C02 NON-ROUTINE MAINTENANCE

The Contractor shall comply with the requirements of the Fault Call-Out Procedure, included in Attachment E, and this specification. Faults have been defined as 'Escalated', 'Major' (refer to Table 751.C1), and 'Other' (refer Table 751.C2).

On being notified of a fault the Contractor shall dispatch qualified technical personnel to attend site and rectify the fault within the times specified in this section. Upon attendance, the Contractor shall:

• make the site safe;

• make the device operational and ensure the device is in normal operational condition;

• complete remedial works, when required, temporary repairs shall be initiated immediately by the Contractor to ensure the site is in a safe, operating state;

• before leaving site carry out a burn out run in accordance with the specified requirements in Part H, Routine Maintenance Activities.

The Contractor shall record all Non-Routine Attendances on the Maintenance Record Card.


HP For all 'Critical', 'Escalated' and 'Major' faults the Contractor shall advise TMC before leaving site. The Contractor shall, on request, provide status reports or other relevant information at any time to TMC or the Superintendent.

HP Where the fault cannot be rectified within the specified period, the Contractor shall contact the Superintendent immediately and advise:

(a) site location;

(b) relevant fault details;

(c) why the fault cannot be rectified in the specified period;

(d) proposed action plan;

(e) estimated time for rectification.

The Contractor shall ensure the proposed 'Action Plan' and 'Estimated time for rectification' noted above are to the satisfaction of the Superintendent and comply with the specified requirements.

The Contractor shall, before 1400 hours the next working day, submit to the Superintendent a ' Non-Routine Attendance Non-Conformance Report (Confirmation)' confirming the following:

• details of the works already done;

• details of the works yet to be completed;

• request Superintendent's approval for an extension of time.

Where a 'Non-Routine Attendance Non-Conformance Report' is not accepted by the Superintendent, the Contractor may be requested to submit a revised 'Action plan' and 'Estimated time for rectification'. If the revised plan is deemed insufficient, deductions may be applied to the contract payment.

The Contractor will not be entitled to additional costs for any Non-Routine Attendance Non-Conformance accepted by the Superintendent.

751.C03 TIME TO ATTEND AND RECTIFY FAULT

The Contractor shall ensure that sufficient equipment and resources are utilised to complete, wherever possible, fault rectification with a single attendance to the site.

Initial Attendance ('Major', 'Escalated' and 'Critical') is the maximum permissible period after the Contractor has been notified of the fault to the commencement of fault rectification.

Rectification time is the maximum permissible period from the Contractor being notified of a fault and returning the asset/device to normal operation mode and completing all remedial works necessary.

For all faults nominated as 'Major' in Table 751.C1, the time for Initial Attendance is two (2) hours. The Contractor shall attend site, make the site safe and commence fault rectification within the Initial Attendance of two (2) hours. The Contractor shall rectify faults and restore the asset/device to normal operation within the time specified for Rectification in Table 751.C1.

For 'Major' and 'Escalated' faults, no additional time shall be granted for Saturdays, Sundays or public holidays that occur within the Rectification period.

For all faults nominated as 'Escalated' the Contractor shall, as directed by the Superintendent, attend site, make the site safe, rectify faults, restore the asset/device to normal operation, and undertake other works reasonably considered by the Superintendent as necessary.

For all faults nominated as 'Other' in Table 751.C2, the Contractor shall attend site, make the site safe, rectify the fault, and restore the asset/device to normal status within the time specified for rectification. Where the time for rectification of a fault expires on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday, the Contractor may complete rectification of the fault on the next working day provided it is by the corresponding hour of day.


Contractors should note that the Reported Fault description applies to all asset types.

751.C04 MEASUREMENT OF RECTIFICATION TIME

The time for 'Initial Attendance' and 'Rectification' are measured concurrently and commence when the fault is notified to the Contractor. Temporary repairs are considered part of the rectification time and shall not be considered the basis for allowing an extension of time for rectification of the fault.

751.C05 TEMPORARY REPAIRS

If an asset cannot be reinstated/repaired by the Contractor at the Initial Attendance, the Contractor shall without delay provide temporary equipment to allow the asset to operate normally. The Contractor shall maintain all temporary equipment until it is replaced with permanent standard equipment. Temporary equipment may comprise but is not limited to temporary posts and/or supports, all necessary wiring and connections for signal lanterns, pedestrian lanterns, pedestrian detectors and illuminated signs.


Temporary equipment may be used in instances where:

• pedestrian detector damaged;

• the affected display is the only primary display;

• the remaining displays are not operational/clearly visible;

• 60% or more vehicle/pedestrian aspects on each signal group are operational/clearly visible;

• all secondary or tertiary displays are inoperative/not clearly visible;

• the controller has been damaged to an extent that it cannot be temporarily retained;

• in the opinion of the Superintendent, the display, post, detector or other accessory is critical to the operation of the site.

Electrical Hardware, Equipment and Cable

Where any electrical hardware, equipment or cable is to be temporarily left in other than normally terminated condition, the Contractor shall ensure that a safe and effective condition of electrical isolation is implemented.

Signal Pedestals

Where a damaged pedestal is to be retained for the purpose of temporary repairs the Contractor shall ensure all displays are positioned to be properly visible, pedestrian detectors are accessible, all accessories are safe, not liable to damage from passing traffic, and does not obstruct pedestrian traffic. All temporary pedestals shall not lean greater than 15 degrees and shall be securely anchored such that they cannot be dislodged or toppled by wind, passing traffic or vandalism.

The Contractor shall provide all necessary ancillary hardware and equipment such as lanterns, cable, detectors, brackets, stabilisation, temporary traffic signal pedestals (including temporary drums) and protection if a pedestal cannot be replaced immediately.

Street Lighting

The Contractor shall reinstate crash damaged VicRoads owned and operated street lighting installed on traffic signal assets. The Contractor shall supply all necessary materials, plant and labour to make the lighting operational.

The maintenance Contractor shall not be responsible for routine maintenance of street lighting assets.

Controllers and Cabinets

Where a damaged controller is to be retained it shall be secured to ensure it is electrically safe, weatherproof, securely fastened shut, not liable to damage from passing traffic and does not obstruct pedestrian traffic. Where a controller is to be secured temporarily it shall not lean greater than 15 degrees and shall be securely anchored such that it cannot be dislodged or toppled by wind, passing traffic or vandalism.

During any fault repairs interchangeable controller parts that are not the same brand and model as that of the controller are to be used as a temporary measure only. Original or repaired parts of the same brand and model as that of the controller are to be re-instated within 48 hours.

With the exception of pedestrian signals, where a controller cannot be retained for temporary repairs, a device to establish 'flashing amber' operation will be promptly installed for no longer than the rectification time specified in Table 751.C1.

The Contractor is responsible for supply, program and install new EPROM and PCMCIA card and complete any required software/firmware updates to facilitate correct operation of the assets. For traffic signal controllers, personality file will be supplied by VicRoads. The Contractor shall have at his disposal suitable programming equipment in order to be able to utilise '*.SFT' format files supplied by VicRoads.

Help Telephones

Where a help telephone is inoperative the Contractor shall ensure 'Out of Order' tape is clearly displayed and secured around the pillar or housing at handset level.


Foundations, Footings, Pits and Exposed Conduits

The Contractor shall ensure that where any foundations, footings, pits and conduits are temporarily left exposed these shall be made safe, properly signed and protected by barricades.

Debris

The Contractor shall ensure all debris is removed. Where it is not possible to remove debris at the initial attendance the Contractor shall ensure the debris is made safe, properly signed and protected by barricades.

The Contractor will not be entitled to additional costs associated with temporary repairs.

751.C06 DAMAGE TO VICROADS ASSETS

(a) Crash Damage

Any crash damage to an asset included in the Contract is to be repaired and replaced by the Contractor as part of the lump sum. Any paved or unpaved areas that have damaged as a result of crash involving electrical hardware maintained under this Contract shall be reinstated by the Contractor as part of the lump sum.

A report shall be submitted as per Clause 751.E06.

(b) Third Party Damage

Under this clause third party is any party other than VicRoads and the Contractor. Third party damage is any damage caused as a result of third party works.

Any asset that requires reinstatement/relocation due to third party damage or programmed works is to be part of the lump sum.

Where damage to VicRoads assets has occurred, the Contractor shall advise to the Superintendent the name of the party responsible for the damage.

(c) Rectification of Detector Loops/Wireless Sensors

Where it is not possible to rectify detector loop(s)/wireless sensors due to works by others (e.g. roadwork, tram maintenance etc.), the Contractor shall monitor the location, liaise and coordinate with the responsible party on site, and ensure rectification is implemented as soon as the works are sufficiently complete to allow such.

If the Contractor fails to co-ordinate and ensure the rectification of the detector loop by the responsible party, any detector loops/wireless sensors damaged by the responsible party shall be repaired by the Contractor within 168 hours as directed by the Superintendent as part of the lump sum.

751.C07 REINSTATEMENT

The Contractor shall reinstate or arrange reinstatement (some councils may prefer to reinstate themselves) to its original state all ground areas disturbed in the course of fault rectification. This shall include but not be limited to:

• concrete paving;

• brick or mortar pavers;

• bitumen or asphalt;

• soil and grass.

The Contractor shall:

• comply with all requirements of the relevant road authorities;

• reinstate the disturbed areas to match surrounds regardless of original condition;

• reinstate the disturbed areas to the satisfaction of the Superintendent.

751.C08 GRAFFITI

The Contractor shall report all graffiti on VicRoads assets maintained under this Contract as part of the lump sum. Graffiti that is considered dangerous shall be removed in accordance with Table 751.C1.

The Contractor shall report all incidences of graffiti on VicRoads traffic signals and other on-road electrical and communication devices as specified in Clause 751.E12. Graffiti that may be considered dangerous shall be specifically identified in the report.


PART 751.D - PLANT, MATERIALS AND HARDWARE

751.D01 TYPE APPROVAL

All hardware supplied by the Contractor shall be type approved by VicRoads.

A list of Type Approved items is provided at:

http://www.vicroads.vic.gov.au/itsspecs (Attachment F).

751.D02 HARDWARE ITEMS TO BE SUPPLIED TO SITE BY VICROADS

VicRoads will supply the following nominated hardware items:

(a) Traffic signal controllers;

(b) Mast Arm bases and outreaches;

(c) Joint Use poles;

(d) Joint Use Mast Arm bases and extensions.

Traffic Signal Controllers will be supplied and connected at the controller foundation. The Contractor shall ensure the controller foundation and all electrical connections are available and ready for connection at the time of supply. The Contractor shall reasonably co-operate with controller installation to ensure prompt fault rectification.

For Mast Arm bases, Mast Arm outreaches, Joint Use poles, Joint Use Mast Arm bases and Joint Use Mast Arm extensions the Contractor shall reasonably co-operate with the supply to ensure prompt fault rectification. The Contractor install these items at the time of supply.

The Contractor shall request these items on a timely basis to ensure prompt rectification of faults.

751.D03 HARDWARE ITEMS SUPPLIED BY CONTRACTOR

With the exception of the items in Clause 751.D02, the Contractor shall supply all hardware/components/materials in order to maintain the assets under this Contract.

Cable

The Contractor shall replace damaged cables full length.

Used and Repaired Hardware and Components

The Contractor may utilise used and repaired hardware and components provided that:

• he inspects and services the item prior to installation;

• he ensures the item is type approved/compatible with the asset to which it is to be installed.

The Contractor shall not utilise used and/or repaired hardware and components that:

• the condition of which may reduce the service life of the asset;

• do not meet the requirements of this specification or the nominated relevant specifications;

• in the opinion of the Superintendent, do not meet the necessary performance or reliability characteristics;

• the repair of foundations shall not be approved unless individual certification from a third party engineering consultant is submitted together with work method statement and job safety analysis.

LEDs

LEDs are to be supplied by the Contractor as part of the lump sum.

Target Boards:

All target boards supplied by the Contractor shall be Type Approved metal target boards.


751.D04 VICROADS SUPPLIED HOLDING STOCK

The Superintendent may supply to the Contractor an initial quantity of hardware and components listed in Attachment G.

The Contractor shall store and use items of this Holding Stock for rectification of faults to VicRoads assets. Such items shall remain the property of VicRoads and shall be returned or replaced, in good working order, at the end of the Contract or at the request of the Superintendent.

VicRoads supply of Holding Stock will occur once. The Contractor shall, in accordance with Clause 751.D06, provide all holding stock required.

The Contractor shall maintain accurate records as to the use of this stock. These records will be provided to the Superintendent on request.

The records shall, for each item of hardware or component supplied, provide as a minimum:

(a) a description of the item such that it can be readily identified;

(b) where each item is stored;

(c) the original quantity supplied;

(d) the current unused quantity of the item;

(e) the serial numbers of unused items;

(f) the used quantity of each item including -

(i) the date the item was installed,

(ii) the site number where the item was installed,

(iii) the serial number of the item.

The record shall be provided in a format in accordance with Clause 751.E10.

751.D05 NEW TECHNOLOGY

VicRoads may at any stage during the Contract introduce new technology into its network of assets. The Contractor shall, as part of the lump sum, obtain any spare parts that are required and sufficiently train its staff so that it is capable of maintaining any new technology in accordance with the requirements of the Contract and/or the manufacturer's requirements.

751.D06 CONTRACTOR SUPPLIED SPARES

The Contractor shall supply, manage and replenish spares necessary to provide an effective and efficient maintenance service in accordance with the specified requirements.

The time to supply hardware or a component item shall not be accepted as a claim for an extension of time to rectify a fault.

751.D07 SERIAL NUMBERS

The Contractor shall allocate and place serial numbers on any electrical/electronic component parts not marked/identified by suppliers, record such in the stock inventory system, and include where specified on reports.

751.D08 IDENTIFICATION DECALS, INSTRUCTION DECALS AND MAINTENANCE RECORD CARDS

Identification decals, instruction decals and Maintenance Record Cards shall conform to the samples provided in Attachment H.


PART 751.E - REPORTING AND MONITORING

751.E01 ASSET CONDITION SURVEYS

(a) Initial Condition Survey

Within the completion of the first routine service of the Contract an Initial Condition Survey of the assets shall be carried out by the Contractor. Joint inspections with the Superintendent may be arranged for elements outside specified requirements.

The purpose of this Initial Condition Survey is to establish and record type, number and condition of the assets. Elements that are outside specified requirements may be permitted to remain in current condition unless otherwise directed or advised by the Superintendent. If the Contractor fails to complete the Initial Condition Survey within the allocated period, no extension of time is given in writing, and the Superintendent may decide on the condition of any asset feature under the contract and its ruling is deemed final.

The Superintendent will provide a response to the Initial Condition Survey submission within 14 days of the receipt. The Superintendent's ruling on the condition of any asset feature element will be final.

Any faults that have not been identified as part of the Initial Condition Survey are to be rectified by the Contractor at its costs.

(b) Asset Condition Survey

The Superintendent may require the Contractor at any given time to participate in an additional Asset Condition Survey to validate that maintenance works are being conducted in accordance with the requirements of the Contract. The Superintendent will provide at least 48 hours notice in writing to the Contractor of the intention to conduct such a survey and its extent.

The Superintendent will provide a written response to the Asset Condition Survey to the Contractor within 14 days of receipt. The Superintendent's ruling on the condition of any asset feature element will be final.

(c) Contract Completion Condition Survey

Not later than 21 days prior to the Date of Practical Completion of the Contract, the Contractor and Superintendent shall conduct a Contract Completion Condition Survey of the whole of the asset to record the current condition of the assets.

Where asset feature elements are identified outside the specified requirements the Superintendent may:

(i) direct the Contractor to bring the deficient asset feature elements to within the specified requirements within a period to be determined by the Superintendent;

(ii) arrange for the rectification of those features by others and in this event a deduction will be made to the Contract Sum for the full cost of such works.

The Superintendent will provide a written response to the Contract Completion Condition Survey to the Contractor within 14 days of receipt. The Superintendent's ruling on the condition of any asset feature element will be final.

751.E02 ACTIVITY REPORTS - GENERAL

The Contractor shall, throughout the term of the Contract, keep and maintain accurate records of all maintenance functions undertaken. The Contractor shall complete and retain individual report sheets for each maintenance function for each site.

All reports concerning electrical/electronic component parts shall quote the serial number.

The Contractor shall provide the following reports listed in Table 751.E021.
