751.E03 ROUTINE SERVICE REPORT AND BURN OUT RUN REPORT

Routine maintenance reports shall be provided by the Contractor using the report formats in Attachment I, and shall record all details of each visit to a site including:

• faults detected;

• time of arrival;

• time of departure;

• works undertaken.


Routine Service and Burn Out Run Reports shall be filed per maintenance activity per maintenance group in site number order and be retained in a secure and audit-able environment by the Contractor. At the completion of the Contract, the Contractor shall box the reports in site number order, and provide these to the Superintendent for archiving. The Contractor shall clearly label and number each box and provide to the Superintendent a report identifying the contents of each box and corresponding box number.

All Routine Service Reports and Burn Out Run Reports whilst stored by the Contractor shall be accessible to the Superintendent on twenty-four hours notice for audit or other purposes.

The Contractor shall provide a Routine Service Report or Burn Out Run Report for each site attended for each routine service or burn out run.

The Contractor shall record all required information while on site, and shall provide all information nominated on the reports.

751.E04 NON-ROUTINE ATTENDANCE REPORT

All Non-Routine Attendances shall be recorded on the Maintenance Record Card. All Non-Routine Attendance Reports shall be submitted to the Superintendent in electronic format.

(a) Hardcopy (Original On-Site) Reports

The Contractor shall use as a minimum the Non-Routine Attendance Report (hardcopy) attached in Attachment J for each attendance.

The Contractor shall complete the Non-Routine Attendance Report on site while attending the fault and shall provide all information nominated on the report as a minimum.

The Contractor shall complete a Non-Routine Attendance Report for each attendance to site even where multiple attendances are necessary or required for the same fault.

Non-Routine Attendance Reports shall be filed in chronological order per maintenance group/site number and be retained in a secure and audit-able. At the completion of the Contract, the Contractor shall box the reports in file order and provide these to the Superintendent for archiving. The Contractor shall clearly label and number each box and provide to the Superintendent a report identifying the contents of each box and corresponding box number.

All Non-Routine Attendance Reports whilst stored by the Contractor shall be accessible to the Superintendent on twenty-four hours notice for audit or other purposes.

(b) Electronic Copy Reports

The electronic copy for the Non-Routine Attendance Report shall include as a minimum the following details:

(i) fault number;

(ii) name of technician and company attending the fault;

(iii) date and time of arrival on site and the status of the site on arrival;

(iv) date and time of rectification;

(v) details and actions undertaken during the attendance together with all equipment used to remedy or repair the reported fault;

(vi) details of items requiring follow-up actions;

(vii) operational status of the device of departure, time and date of departure;

(viii) status of display of the device during attendance.

The Contractor shall provide the electronic copy 'Non-Routine Attendance Report' to the Superintendent by 1400 hours the following working day.


751.E05 NON-ROUTINE ATTENDANCE NON-CONFORMANCE REPORT (CONFIRMATION)

Where an asset cannot be reinstated/repaired within the period specified, a report shall be submitted to the Superintendent detailing:

(a) RAI fault number;

(b) site number;

(c) site location;

(d) details of the fault;

(e) why the fault could not be rectified within the specified period;

(f) Action Plan to be implemented by the Contractor - if third party, name of company and contact details;

(g) estimated time/date of rectification and any supporting documentation;

(h) the Superintendent the original report was made to;

(i) any further details necessary to assist the Superintendent to evaluate the non-conformance.

This report shall be in addition to the immediate notification provided by the Contractor to the Superintendent at the time of the non-conformance.

The Contractor shall use the Non-Routine Attendance Non-Conformance Report (Confirmation) attached in Attachment K.

The Contractor shall provide the Non-Routine Attendance Non-Conformance Report (Confirmation) to the Superintendent before 1400 hours the next working day.

751.E06 CRASH DAMAGE REPORT

Where a fault is the result of crash damage the Contractor shall advise to the Superintendent any relevant vehicle registration numbers that are on site at the time of attendance.

The Contractor shall record all details of time, labour, and hardware used to correct faults caused by crash. The Contractor shall provide the report to the Superintendent within two days of the initial attendance.

The Contractor shall use the Crash Damage Report attached in Attachment L (or an approved electronic version) and shall provide all information nominated on the report.

751.E07 MATERIALS USAGE REPORT

The Contractor shall provide a report detailing the monthly usage and the total-to-date usage of any material item, equipment or spare parts used in the routine and non-routine maintenance of the assets maintained under this Contract. This report shall include materials used monthly for each individual site together with cumulative totals per site from the beginning of the Contract. All replaced and new electrical/electronic parts shall have the serial numbers recorded in the reports.

751.E08 TRAFFIC SIGNAL DISPLAY PERFORMANCE REPORT

The Contractor shall provide graphs and data tables illustrating the monthly totals of:

(a) incandescent globes replaced;

(b) quartz halogen globes replaced;

(c) LED displays replaced;

(d) combined number of incandescent and quartz halogen globes replaced.

Each of the above shall be expressed as percentages of the total number of displays for the traffic signal maintenance group.

The graphs shall illustrate the above data for each month and all preceding months of the Contract, and the Contractor shall supply any supporting documentation upon request.


751.E09 NON-ROUTINE ATTENDANCE PERFORMANCE

The Contractor shall provide graphs and data tables illustrating the monthly totals, per Maintenance Group, for the number of:

(a) faults notified to the Contractor;

(b) faults attended by the Contractor;

(c) faults rectified by the Contractor;

(d) faults attended within the specified interval by the Contractor;

(e) faults rectified within the specified interval by the Contractor;

(f) faults where an extension of time has been requested by the Contractor;

(g) faults where a Contractor requested extension of time has been approved by the Superintendent.

All missed attendances/rectifications shall have the site and RAI job number specified in a table.

The graphs shall illustrate the above data for each month and all preceding months of the Contract. These times shall be based on the VicRoads Road Asset Inventory (RAI) system times.

751.E10 REPORT FORMAT

All reports provided to the Superintendent by the Contractor shall be:

• produced using Microsoft Excel or in a format approved;

• in full colour suitable size hard copy and electronically on CD/DVD‑ROM disk.

751.E11 MAINTENANCE RECORD CARD

The Contractor shall record details on the Maintenance Record Card of each attendance to a site. Maintenance Record Card shall remain on site.

The Contractor shall ensure the Maintenance Record Cards are maintained in clear and legible writing and are kept clean, dry and complete. The site number shall be recorded on both sides of the card.

The Contractor shall supply and replace Maintenance Record Cards when necessary.

751.E12 GRAFFITI

The Contractor shall provide monthly written reports regarding graffiti removed in the course of works.

The following information shall be provided by the Contractor:

(a) site number and location;

(b) form of graffiti (e.g. paint, marker, paper, etc.);

(c) estimated coverage area;

(d) if a billposter, full details of the advertisement.

751.E13 INCIDENT REPORTING

(a) Fatal Crashes, Crashes at Contractor's Work Sites, Damage to VicRoads' Property

(i) If a fatal crash occurs before call-out Non-Routine Attendance the Contractor he shall immediately report the occurrence to the Superintendent.

(ii) If a fatal crash occurs or when any crash occurs at works being done by the Contractor he shall immediately report the occurrence to the Superintendent.


The Contractor shall submit a written report in a format acceptable to the Superintendent within twenty‑four (24) hours of the Contractor being involved/aware of an incident where any of the following has occurred:

• VicRoads property is damaged;

• the crash involves a fatality, or serious injury involving the public or Contractor's employee;

• a crash occurs in the near vicinity (e.g. at the traffic signal intersection or on the freeway near a Help telephone) at which work is being carried out by the Contractor;

• any incident involving WorkSafe Victoria.

The report shall include:

• details of the crash scene showing the location of all signage (including wording), all lights, and pavement markings, etc;

• where any vehicle hits a roadside obstacle or VicRoads asset.

(b) Notice of Incident

The Contractor shall supply to the Superintendent within seven days of receiving a Notice of Incident a summary of all inspections, maintenance and repairs conducted by the Contractor in the 12 months period before the date of the incident and any other relevant information available to the Contractor to enable completion of the Condition Report.

(c) Cost Recoupment

The contractor shall provide the Superintendent with all costing details related to the incident. This shall include a breakdown of all associated costs.


PART 751.F - EMERGENCY RESPONSE

751.F01 GENERAL

Under the Emergency Management Act, VicRoads has statutory responsibility to meet emergency management obligations as:

• The State Road Authority for Victoria;

• A Support agency or the lead agency for Transport, Engineering and Services Support (TESS) under Victoria's State Emergency Response Plan (SERP).

The roles in routine emergency incidents on roads over which VicRoads exercises control include:

• providing manpower, equipment and materials to clear and/or make roads safe;

• providing appropriate signing and traffic control assistance;

• selecting and establishing appropriate alternative detour routes;

• providing information to the public on road and traffic conditions.

When required under the provisions of the SERP, VicRoads provides assistance to control agencies which includes:

• fulfilling the same roles as for emergency incidents;

• assisting with the management of all road links, which can include emergency traffic management, escorting, route conditions and advice;

• providing support advice on transport and engineering matters which can include facilitating special transport needs and engineering advice such as the safety of bridges and land slips.

751.F02 CONTRACTOR REQUIREMENTS

(a) The Contractor is required to provide a 24-hour response capability to ensure safety of the public as a result of emergency incidents, including flooding, fires, storms and traffic crashes that include Traffic Control Systems.

(b) The Contractor shall comply with a VicRoads' request for emergency response and make available any resources used in conjunction with this Contract. All directions and supervision for VicRoads Emergency Management Plan activities shall be through the Superintendent or advised by the VicRoads TMC and undertaken as Provisional Works.

(c) Control agencies for emergency response operations are designated in the Emergency Management Manual Victoria. Notwithstanding the provisions of the Contract, the Contractor shall provide assistance to and follow the directions of any control agency.

(d) If a section of road is affected by an emergency incident, the Contractor shall provide appropriate assistance.

The Superintendent will provide the Contractor with one copy of relevant VicRoads Emergency Management Plan documentation for use during the Contract.

Prior to commencement of work on‑site, the Contractor shall provide the Superintendent with details of a single contact to be contactable 24 hours per day, and other contact numbers which will be used by the Contractor during any emergency response.

751.F03 ACTION TO BE TAKEN BY THE CONTRACTOR

(a) Response

Any response is to be registered with the Superintendent or the VicRoads TMC. The Superintendent may direct that additional Contractor resources be provided and paid for as dayworks, or arrange for the work to be carried out by others.

The Contractor shall co‑operate with the control agency and other emergency services.


(b) Advise VicRoads TMC

The Contractor shall advise the VicRoads TMC as soon as practicable of all requests for assistance from the Victoria Police or other control agency.

The Contractor shall inform the VicRoads TMC when the traffic on any section is likely to be delayed even for a short time by an incident.

Situation reports shall be made to the VicRoads TMC for the duration of the emergency at not more than hourly intervals.

The Contractor shall advise the VicRoads TMC when the cause of any delay or stoppage has been removed or has passed.

(c) Emergency Incident Recording

For each emergency the following additional information shall be recorded:

(i) 'Time of Call', to nearest 1/4 of an hour, being the actual time the Contractor receives the call to attend to an incident (start of call out).

(ii) 'Time Arrive on Site', to nearest 1/4 of an hour, being the actual time the Initial Emergency Response Unit arrives at the incident site.

(iii) 'Time Site Opened', to nearest 1/4 of an hour, being the actual time the site is substantially re‑opened to normal traffic operation. If the site is already open or does not involve closure of traffic lanes then 'Time Site Opened' is recorded the same as 'Time Arrive on Site'.

(iv) 'Time Contractor Leaves Site', to nearest 1/4 of an hour, being the actual time the Contractor leaves the site (end of call out).

(v) 'Opening Control' requires the recording of one of the following to indicate who controlled re‑opening the site to traffic ‑

V = VicRoads P = Police E = Other Emergency Services

For each incident that involves closure of or affects one or more traffic lanes the Contractor shall submit to the Superintendent along with work done data of this specification, time of call, attendance and site opening details.

Where damage has been caused to VicRoads property, this shall be clearly detailed on the crash report to the Superintendent who may direct the repairs to be undertaken as dayworks or arrange it to be done by others.

751.H02 PROGRAM AND PROGRESS - WHOLE OF WORKS

(a) Interpretation

For the purposes of this clause, 'works program' means a program in the format of a network orientated activity which indicates how the Contractor proposes to schedule Routine Maintenance in accordance with Table 751.H011.

(b) Works Program Requirements

HP Before commencing work under the Contract, the Contractor shall submit for review a works program illustrating the planned sequence of work. The works program shall include the principal activities to be undertaken and restraints clearly identified with a time scale shown in weeks and months.

The works program shall:

(i) include dates for starting and completion of each Routine Maintenance activity per asset type;

(ii) show details of activities with corresponding durations in days;

(iii) show plant and labour resources planned for each activity;

(iv) provide a baseline for review of performance as the Contract proceeds.

The works program shall be computer based using 'Microsoft Project' or an alternative computer program approved by the Superintendent and shall be submitted on CD/DVD-ROM disc and hard copy.

(c) Review of Submitted Works Program

If the Superintendent considers that the submitted works program, or any subsequent revision, does not show sufficient details, is impractical or does not comply with the requirements of this Contract, the Superintendent may direct the Contractor to resubmit an amended program within seven (7) days for further review.

(d) Review of Progress

Further to the requirements of Clause 163.D1, the Contractor shall update the works program to indicate actual progress on the works for review by the Superintendent on a monthly basis.

(e) Updating and Reporting on Program

The Contractor shall maintain a complete record of the works program and its changes electronically and hardcopy, throughout the Contract.

(i) The Contractor shall submit to the Superintendent updated programs:

1. within fourteen (14) days of any change to the plant and/or labour resources planned for each activity;

2. within seven (7) days of any changes to the schedule in the works program.


(ii) Updated works program shall provide the same level of detail as the original works program and shall:

1. show the current progress in respect of all works carried out up-to-date;

2. show the original program baseline;

3. be accompanied by a statement of the reasons for changes from the previously submitted works program.

(f) Rate of Progress

Where the Superintendent considers that the rate of progress is insufficient to ensure compliance with the requirements of the Contract, the Superintendent may direct the Contractor to submit within fourteen (14) days written details of the intended procedure in order to meet the work progress schedule for this Contract.

751.H03 PROGRAM AND PROGRESS - DAILY CONFIRMATION

The Contractor shall provide to the Superintendent, in writing, confirmation of the Works Program on a daily basis. This confirmation shall identify: site numbers, asset types and Routine Maintenance activity to be carried out.

The Contractor shall provide this report to the Superintendent before 9am each working day. Where these activities are to be undertaken outside of office hours the Contractor shall provide this report on the preceding working day.

Changes to this confirmation shall be notified to the Superintendent immediately.

751.H04 TRAFFIC SIGNALS AND MISCELLANEOUS CONTROL AND WARNING DEVICES

Traffic signals, miscellaneous control and warning devices shall be maintained to achieve the functional requirements specified under this Contract. This includes but is not limited to items listed in Tables 751.H041 and 751.H042.

Table 751.H041 Traffic Signals, Miscellaneous Control and Warning Devices: Burn Out Run

BURN OUT RUN - TRAFFIC SIGNALS, MISCELLANEOUS CONTROL AND WARNING DEVICES

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

1

Ensure all displays/pixels correctly operate and are aligned.

Inspect and, where inoperative, obscured, dull or damaged, make good all vehicle and pedestrian displays, including advisory and warning displays, repair/replace defective lamp holders.

Inspect all vehicle and pedestrian displays, including advisory and warning displays, align, tighten and secure.

Check, align and clean all gantry electronic and static signs if required.

2

Ensure ancillary hardware is intact and properly secured.

Repair, align and replace all faulty, damaged or missing visors, louvres, and damaged target boards.

Replace all damaged, obscured, missing or faulty lenses, masks and reflectors.

Replace all damaged or missing finial caps.

3

Check and reset fault log.

Record on maintenance card all current fault references and manually reset the controller fault log via the Keyboard Display Unit.

Record all faults from slave units.


Table 751.H042 Traffic Signals, Miscellaneous Control and Warning Devices: Routine Service

ROUTINE SERVICE - TRAFFIC SIGNALS, MISCELLANEOUS CONTROL AND WARNING DEVICES

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

1

Inspect pedestals and gantries and all pedestal/ gantry mounted equipment.

If rag-bolts are not encased in mortar, expose, inspect, tighten to specified torque, secure and ensure there is no debris covering base.

Inspect all pole mounted equipment and re-tension nuts, bolts and other fasteners. Repair or replace all faulty, damaged or missing fixing accessories (i.e. brackets, washers, nuts and bolts etc).

Inspect and ensure termination boxes, seals and cable glands are in good condition and tight.

Remove and clean all cobwebs, road grime, adhesives, chewing gum, etc.

Check and ensure all wiring is secure.

Replace all damaged or missing finial caps.

2

Ensure displays and ancillary hardware is operational, intact, secure and undamaged.

Inspect, repair or replace all faulty/dull displays and/or lanterns.

Inspect all displays, align, tighten and secure.

Replace all faulty and damaged fixing accessories (i.e. brackets, washers, nuts and bolts etc).

Repair or replace faulty and damaged displays.

Clean and completely remove all road grime, cobwebs and foreign material from all lenses/reflectors, glassware, etc.

3

Ensure cabinets and other traffic control devices' housing is intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Remove and clean all contamination and foreign materials including water, litter, organic material, cobwebs, road grime, adhesives, chewing gum, sharps etc. Clean and wash down entire surfaces.

Record, report and remove graffiti as per Clause 751.C08.

Inspect and ensure that controller cabinets are secure and waterproof, locks and hinges operational.

Repair, adjust re-seal or lubricate as necessary.

Inspect and ensure that the interior of controller cabinet is clean and free from ingress of rodents, insects or other pests or foreign materials and apply pesticides.

Check all slave units wiring and seals ensuring position and condition.

Obtain voltage minimum and maximum reading and record it on maintenance card and on the routine sheets.

If applicable, check and test RCDs as per AS 3760.

4

Ensure proper operation of control relays and contacts.

Inspect control relays and contacts, and replace if showing signs of advanced deterioration or considered potential to fault.

Replace when damaged or deteriorated.

5

Ensure all wiring and cabling is securely connected and supported.

Inspect for loose wires on all accessible terminals, and re-terminate and tighten.

Inspect and ensure all cable supports are secure.

6

Ensure PTF RAM backup battery is charged and operates correctly.

Confirm 6 volt PTF RAM backup battery operating. If voltage less than 6 volts replace battery.

Clean and coat 6-volt PTF RAM backup battery terminals with suitable anti-corrosive.

Replace PTF RAM backup battery every 12 months.

7

Ensure proper operation of flasher unit.

Repair or replace if faulty.

751.H05 REGIONAL COMPUTER CABINS

Regional computer cabins shall be maintained to achieve the functional requirements specified under this Contract. This includes but is not limited to items listed in Table 751.H051.

Table 751.H051 Regional Computer Cabins: Routine Service

ROUTINE SERVICE REGIONAL COMPUTER CABINS

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

1

Ensure cabin ante room and computer room are clean, dry, sanitary, illuminated and secure.

Thoroughly clean and sanitise the toilet and hand basin and replace sanitiser pellets where required.

Re-stock the toilet paper holder, hand towel dispenser and soap holder. Inspect and ensure minimum supplies of two (2) rolls of toilet paper, one (1) cake of soap and one (1) roll of hand towel.

Sweep and wash all vinyl floors.

Empty the rubbish bin(s) and dispose of the rubbish. Replace bin liner.

Clean carpeted floors, skirting boards and benches of dust.

Inspect and ensure lighting fixtures are in good working order and replace any faulty globes/tubes.

Inspect for ingress of ants and presence of pests and rodents, eradicate as required.

Inspect and repair any water leaks at ceiling/walls/doors.

Test and ensure telephone operates correctly.

2

Ensure ancillary computer equipment is operational.

Log on at SCATS Regional Computer printer terminal and:

• inspect if computer is operating with no alarm/fault status;

• inspect that Monitor and Hardcopy is operational;

• inspect print quality and replace ribbon where necessary;

• inspect paper on the printer and ensure there is not less than 20 mm of paper available on stack;

• remove printout to prevent overflowing. Stack printout, label start/finish dates and store.

3

Ensure all electronic cards are secure and in proper contact with connectors.

Inspect and ensure all modem and other cards are correctly aligned, connected and in good order.

Inspect and ensure all cards make proper contact with back planes and other terminals.

4

Ensure environmental control system is operational.

Inspect condition of air conditioner filter and clean and/or replace where necessary. Inspect and ensure air conditioner settings are correct.

Inspect and ensure air conditioner and EMP operate correctly and within the specified range of 17‑24 degrees Celsius. Record temperature on arrival and on departure.

Inspect computer cooling fans, and ensure normal operation.

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

Table 751.H081 Trip Information Signs: Routine Service …. continued

ROUTINE SERVICE - TRIP INFORMATION SIGNS

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

2

Ensure internals, circuit boards, wiring, lamps, connections and ancillary equipment are intact, secure and in proper working order.

Inspect and ensure all cables, connectors and sockets are neat and firmly in place.

Inspect and ensure there is no corrosion present on any cards or connectors. Inspect Printed Circuit Boards for brown or black areas on the board, around tracks, and/or components. Replace board if this is detected.

Inspect and ensure all fans on power supply unit(s) operate correctly.

Inspect and ensure any dim or failed fluorescent tubes are replaced and made operative.

Inspect and ensure inside of cabinet is clean and free from dust and debris.

Inspect and ensure fastness of all IDC connectors on alpha modules and printed circuit board panel mounts.

If applicable, check and test RCDs as per AS 3760.

Inspect and ensure that incoming mains earth is connected to earth bar in switchboard and that metalwork is earthed.

Inspect and ensure DC‑to‑DC converters are firmly in place. Inspect and ensure distribution terminals are mounted securely in place onto DIN rails.

Inspect and ensure all power supplies are operating and secured.

Inspect and ensure spade terminals of LED and Fibre Optic Globe power lines are firmly in place at each module and at switch mode power supply. Inspect and ensure all cards in PC are securely in place and that IO cables are connected and firmly in place.

Inspect and ensure all terminal block data, ground and status wires are firmly in place on terminal.

Inspect and ensure labels are in place and secure.

Inspect and ensure all light dimming connectors and wires are in place. Inspect and ensure correct operation of temperature sensor.

Inspect and ensure all modules are tightly in place.

Measure, record and ensure correct operation of power supplies.

Inspect and ensure all power LED's are illuminated. Inspect and ensure all PC power LEDs are illuminated. Measure, record and ensure correct input voltages to PC. Inspect and ensure NTU/telephone power is correct and operating.

3

Ensure functionality and operation of fibre optic components.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic harnesses are well supported and are not kinked or bent.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic cables do not kink when doors close.

Inspect and ensure all (primary and secondary) fibre optic globes operate.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic lamp reflectors and mirrors are clean, unstained and unmarked. Replace as necessary.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic ferrules are in place, secure, undistorted and uncracked. Replace as necessary.

Inspect and ensure operation of 'Lamp Change Over' capability for both 'lamp failure' and peaked/dimmed operational requirements.

Inspect and ensure light box is secure, undamaged and correctly aligned.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic harnesses are securely held in place in the light box and in the optimum position for the focal characteristics of the reflector and globe.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic colour and/or heat filters are in place, undamaged and that the optimum location of light source to fibre optic harness is maintained.


Table 751.H081 Trip Information Signs: Routine Service …. continued

ROUTINE SERVICE - TRIP INFORMATION SIGNS

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

4

Ensure proper operation of cooling system.

Inspect and ensure that vents are clean.

Inspect and ensure fans operate correctly and that there is no indication of wear. Replace or repair as necessary.

Ensure thermostat is operating correctly.

5

Ensure proper condition and operation of battery.

Inspect and ensure battery terminals are properly secure.

Inspect and ensure battery terminals and casings are clean and free of salt growth and that battery casings are not cracked or leaking.

Replace batteries if leaking or damaged.

Disconnect 240v-power supply and inspect and ensure the AC fail LED illuminates.

Inspect and ensure operation of 'Battery Low' LED.

• stuck pixels;

• half turned pixels;

• dislodged/misaligned spindles;

• missing pixel dots;

• misaligned modules;

• slow pixels;

• incorrect column/row operation;

• uneven pixel display across a module or character.

Perform routine service as per manufacturer's specification.

3

Ensure all wiring and cabling is securely connected and supported.

Inspect for loose wires on all accessible terminals, and re-terminate and tighten.

Inspect and ensure all cable supports are secure and in proper working order.

4

Ensure proper connection and housing of meter and power supply facilities (where applicable).

Inspect housing of meter and power supply facilities; arrange power authority to repair if required.

Inspect and ensure optimum operation of the solar charge control module (where installed). Arrange vegetation trimming to keep solar panel uncovered.

Inspect and ensure optimum operation and integrity of solar panels and batteries (where installed). Inspect and ensure batteries maintain charge sufficient for continuous operation 24 hours, 7 days a week.

5

Ensure pits and covers are safe, secure and intact.

Inspect, repair or replace defective pit lids and concrete surrounds.

6

Ensure proper operation of communication facilities.

Perform an operational test by calling TMC and proving the operation.

Inspect the operation of the ring tone by dialling the call back number and listening to the tone.

Inspect antenna for damage, replace/refit if required and ensure operation.

7

Ensure VicRoads stickers are intact and legible.

Clean or replace stickers as necessary.


751.H13 CCTV

CCTV devices shall be maintained to achieve the functional requirements specified under this Contract. This includes but is not limited to items listed in Table 751.H131.

Table 751.H131 CCTV: Routine Service

ROUTINE SERVICE - CCTV

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

1

Ensure pedestals and all pole mounted equipment is intact, secure and undamaged.

Ensure pole is secure at base and tighten rag bolts as necessary. Inspect and ensure locks, where fitted, are secure.

For hinged poles ensure counterweight is secure and pole operation is smooth and balanced.

Inspect all pole-mounted equipment and tighten bolts. Repair or replace all faulty, damaged or missing fixing accessories (i.e. brackets, washers, nuts and bolts etc.).

2

Ensure cabinets are operational, intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Remove and clean all contamination and foreign materials including water, litter, organic material, cobwebs, road grime, adhesives, chewing gum, sharps etc. Clean and wash down entire surfaces.

Record, report and remove graffiti as per Clause 751.C08.

Inspect and ensure controller cabinets are secure and waterproof, locks and hinges operational. Repair, adjust re-seal or lubricate as necessary.

Inspect and ensure that the interior of controller cabinet is clean and free from ingress of rodents, insects or other pests or foreign materials and apply pesticides.

Record and report program for repair or replacement of items unable to be repaired or replaced at routine service.

3

Ensure all wiring and cabling is securely connected and supported.

Inspect for loose wires on all accessible terminals, and re-terminate and tighten.

Inspect and ensure all cable supports are secure and in proper working order.

4

Ensure all electronic cards are secure and in proper contact with connectors.

Inspect and ensure all modem and other cards are correctly aligned, connected and in good order.

Inspect and ensure all cards make proper contact with back planes and other terminals.

5

Ensure camera housing is intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Inspect and ensure camera and associated enclosure/housing are secure and waterproof, locks and hinges operational. Repair, adjust re-seal or lubricate as necessary.

6

Ensure proper operation of lens.

Inspect and ensure correct back focus. Inspect and ensure auto iris settings for best picture and operation in varied light conditions.

Inspect and ensure correct operation of zoom functions.

Calibrate, clean with appropriate cleaning agent, inspect for damage, repair and record such.

7

Ensure proper operation of pan tilt head.

Inspect and ensure proper and smooth operation to horizontal and vertical extremities.

Inspect and ensure correct speed of all directional travel.

8

Ensure VicRoads stickers are intact and legible.

Clean or replace stickers as necessary.

9

Ensure proper connection and housing of meter and power supply facilities (where required).

Inspect, secure, clean and repair faulty components, and associated hardware (i.e. junction boxes, cabling, housing etc.).

Inspect housing of meter and power supply facilities; arrange power authority to repair if required.

10

Prove proper operation.

After cleaning and inspection, perform an operational test by contacting TMC and confirming all camera functions are operating correctly.

Inspect and ensure a clear undistorted and uninterrupted picture is provided.


751.H14 ICE DETECTION AND WARNING DEVICES

Ice detection and warning devices shall be maintained to achieve the functional requirements specified under this Contract. This includes but is not limited to items listed in Table 751.H141.

Table 751.H141 Ice Detection and Warning Devices: Routine Service

ROUTINE SERVICE - ICE DETECTION AND WARNING DEVICES

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

1

Ensure exterior, housing and doors are clean and functional.

Check and ensure that all displays operate correctly.

Check and repair cabinet for water leaks. Repair or replace door gaskets if leak is at door seals. Ensure inside of cabinet is clean and free from dust and debris.

Check and ensure all doors and locks operate freely and latches are in place.

Clean faces of sensors.

Check all paintwork and ensure any scratches, chips or defects are 'touched up' and match cabinet finish.

Ensure signs and displays are properly aligned.

Record, report and remove graffiti as per Clause 751.C08.

Check and if necessary rectify pedestals and support posts.

Repair or replace lantern and fibre optic sign visors, louvers and target boards if damaged or missing. Remove any foreign material.

Repair or replace lantern lenses, reflectors, hinges or lantern bodies if damaged of missing. Thoroughly clean lenses and reflectors/glassware.

Remove or prune any plant growth obstruction of sign displays.

Ensure sensors are clean and unobstructed. Clean/poison weeds and grass in immediate vicinity of off road detector.

Ensure saw cuts for road sensors and uncracked and completely sealed with approved sealant. Replace sealant if gaps or cracks are present.

2

Ensure interior, circuit boards, wiring and connections are clean and functional.

Check and ensure there is no corrosion present on any cards or connectors.

Check printed circuit boards for brown or black areas on the board, around tracks and/or components. Replace board if this is detected.

Check and ensure all ribbon cables area secure to channels and secure all slack cables.

Check and ensure that all cable ends have strain reliefs in place and are secure.

Check and ensure all power and data cables are securely fastened in terminal blocks.

Check and ensure all 240 volt power cables are clamped in place.

Check and ensure that incoming mains earth is connected to earth bar in switchboard and that metalwork is earthed.

Check and ensure labels are in place.

Check and ensure all light dimming connectors and wires are in place.

3

Perform operational test.

Perform operational test in conjunction with VicRoads and the equipment supplier by liaison on site with the TMC and the supplier. Confirm all functions, including ice detection and other weather station functions, and displays operate correctly.

751.H16 ILLUMINATED AND SPEED ADVISORY SIGNS

Table 751.H161 Illuminated and Speed Advisory Signs: Routine Service

ROUTINE SERVICE - ILLUMINATED AND SPEED ADVISORY SIGNS

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

1

Ensure housing is intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Record, report and remove graffiti as per Clause 751.C08.

Inspect gaskets for deterioration. Replace gaskets if broken or damaged or considered potential to fault.

Inspect and ensure all doors and locks operate freely and latches are in place. Inspect and ensure door rubber seals are in place and joined around perimeter. Remedy any noticeable gaps.

Clean faces of light sensors.

Inspect all paintwork and ensure any scratches, chips or defects are 'touched up' and match cabinet finish.

Repair any corrosion spots.

2

Ensure internal, circuit boards, wiring, lamps, connections and ancillary equipment are intact, secure and in proper working order.

Inspect and ensure there is no corrosion present on any cards or connectors. Inspect Printed Circuit Boards for brown or black areas on the board, around tracks, and/or components. Replace board if this is detected.

Inspect and ensure any dim or failed fluorescent tubes are replaced and made operative.

Inspect and ensure inside of cabinet is clean and free from dust and debris.

Inspect and ensure all power and data cables are securely fastened in terminal blocks. Inspect and ensure all 240 volt power cables are clamped in place.

Inspect and ensure that incoming mains earth is connected to earth bar in switchboard and that metalwork is earthed.

Inspect and ensure all power supplies are operational.

Inspect and ensure spade terminals of LED and Fibre Optic Globe power lines are firmly in place at each module and at switch mode power supply. Inspect and ensure all PC cards and IO cables are securely in place.

Inspect and ensure labels are in place.

Inspect and ensure all light dimming connectors and wires are in place. If necessary align light sensors as required.

Inspect and ensure all modules are tightly in place and each screw is fastened firmly.

Measure, record and ensure correct DC voltages at the inputs and outputs of converters. Measure, record and ensure correct DC voltages at switch mode power supplies. Measure, record and ensure correct input DC voltages at all printed circuit board cards.

Inspect and ensure all power LEDs are illuminated. Inspect and ensure all PC power LEDs are illuminated. Measure, record and ensure correct input voltages to PC. Inspect and ensure NTU/telephone power is correct and operating.

DESCRIPTION

DESCRIPTION

ACTION SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:

Test and ensure proper operation of all flip pixels.

Blank the display then display all on. Repeat this several times using alternative wipes. Inspect and ensure that none of the conditions noted below occur. Repair or replace any faulty items to correct any of the conditions noted below:

• stuck pixels

• half turned pixels

• dislodged/misaligned spindles

• missing pixel dots

• misaligned modules

• inoperative LED clusters

• flashing LED clusters

• slow pixels

• incorrect column/row operation

• uneven pixel display across a module or character

Inspect and ensure PC connects with sign and that sign sends acknowledgement from the sign.

Inspect and ensure the sign performs the following operations, responds to commands and that the PC reported correctly:

• clear signs

• set sign

• hatch

• vertical lines

• horizontal lines

• all 'wipes'.

Inspect and ensure the sign responds to all commands and that the PC reports:

• list stored frames

• list stored scenes

• upload schedule

• remote time

• remote temperature.

9

Ensure correct operation of LEDs, dimming facility and temperature sensor.

Perform routine service as per manufacturer's specification.

Test and prove proper operation.

Check if the speed detectors are calibrated and aligned properly.

Perform operational test in conjunction with VicRoads by contacting TMC and confirming all functions operate correctly.

ATTACHMENT C TO SECTION 751

(Page 1 of 3)

CONNECTION, TEST AND COMMISSION OF SCATS COMMUNICATION LINE

(available on VicRoads website - www.vicroads.vic.gov.au)

Procedure for Commissioning and Connection of SCATS Line

After receipt of connection request from the Superintendent and full job details:

1. determine that the computer has been dimensioned for the requested slot and the required DZ installed;

2. test / repair(i) / install modem as necessary to facilitate line commissioning;

3. Establish status(ii) of line pair to ensure that the line has been jumpered correctly to specified slot (confirmation of this should be obtained via TMC);

4. ensure that the line pair and jumpering information is entered in the MDF record book;

5. confirm correct line pair and modem operation and request the TMC complete a DZ test;

6. record ALL line levels at both 'A' and 'B' ends on or within 48 hours after notification of site controller commission;

7. forward ALL line details either by facsimile or post to the Superintendent for database entry on VicRoads-supplied proforma.

Notes: (i) Any repairs carried out will meet VicRoads standards.

(ii) Report any line diagnosed as faulty to TMC for action, then await response prior to attempting further commissioning of the line and advise the Superintendant of any expected commissioning delays.

Testing of Scats Communications

Set intersection pointer to (n!) or Slot pointer (SL=m!) to the intersection or slot to be tested.

Scats Communications

DZS! STOP SCATS communications for the monitored location

DZS? LIST locations with communications stopped

DZS? START SCATS communications to the monitors location

DZ Test

DZT! START DZ Test on monitored location (INT/SLOT)

NOTE: STOP SCATS communications first, using DZS! to prevent false checksum alarm which may blackout the location when tests are completed!

<esc> press the escape key to terminate the DZ test.

Test Procedure

The local controller must be prevented from responding to the test messages sent by the computer before these tests can be conducted (e.g. isolation plug in Krone block, or pull out plug at local).

The following test procedure can only be done from a SCATS terminal. To start a test, you need a Modem Monitor Card (MMC) or an RX/TX card capable of looping the signal back to the SCATS computer for comparison with the test pattern sent from the computer.


ATTACHMENT C TO SECTION 751

(Page 2 of 3)

CONNECTION, TEST AND COMMISSION OF SCATS COMMUNICATION LINE

Starting a Test

To conduct a test at a location, follow the steps:

n! Set the pointer to the desired location

DZS! STOP normal SCATS communications

DZT! START the DZ test

<esc> press the escape key to exit - this disables the DZ test

DZS/ restore normal SCATS communications

The computer does one pass through a test pattern approximately every 12 seconds. Transmission rate is 300 baud continuous. When a test is in operation, the terminal cannot be used for anything else. There is no limit to the length of time a test can be conducted.

* An asterisk is printed on the terminal after each successful pass.

N The letter N will be displayed instead of an asterisk if the communications test was successful, but no carrier tone was detected by the modem.

Error Codes

*ERROR-BSY* SCATS communications are still active - stop with DZS!

*ERROR-I/O* unable to transmit test message - NO DZ installed or faulty DZ

ERROR - BD S/B xx WAS yy - (bad data)

ERROR - BR baud rate error

ERROR - FE framing error

ERROR - HP hardware parity error

ERROR - OR overrun

ERROR - SY receiver failed to synchronise on test pattern

ERROR - TO receiver did not get complete test pattern

Test Points

• computer

• modem rack

• krone block

• isolation transformer

• local controller

Test at a Region

DZ test in computer - insert an isolation plug into the krone block to isolate the local from the SCATS computer. Loop the signal at the RX/TX card in the modem rack. This may be done with the loop switch on the card, otherwise install an RX/TX card which has been specially modified to loop the signal.

Start the test. A communications error here shows a faulty DZ or RX/TX card. Replace the RX/TX with a known good card. If the fault remains, it is a faulty DZ, so inform the person responsible for the computer hardware (CST).


ATTACHMENT C TO SECTION 751

(Page 3 of 3)

CONNECTION, TEST AND COMMISSION OF SCATS COMMUNICATION LINE

Tests at the Local Location

Before conducting tests at the local, all tests at the region end must be completed first and they must prove negative.

As tests at the local require the controller to be isolated from the SCATS computer, and tests can only be done from a SCATS terminal, the test conditions must be set up at the local and a terminal used from another location, e.g. region terminal, nearby local or requested from the TMC (Traffic Management Centre).

Modem Card Test

If the region tests prove negative, remove the communications processor from the controller and reconnect the communications plug. Install an RX/TX card especially modified to loop the audio signal.

Start the test.

A communications error here shows a faulty module or power supply. Test the power supply. If faulty, replace, then reset. If the power supply is good, replace the module then reset. If no fault is found in any test here, and the local still has communications problem, change the communications processor. If fault still persists, inform the responsible VicRoads regional Computer Cabin Communications officer.


ATTACHMENT D TO SECTION 751

(Page 1 of 6)

FREEWAY DATA STATION MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS

VICROADS FREEWAY DATA STATIONS SYSTEM CHECKS (LIMITED)

1. Introduction

This is a series of visual checks involving the following actions, however they do not indicate 100% system operation. The test assumes that the JED microprocessor card is operating correctly. The test also indicates power on functions of the system and is a limited indication that the communication (comms) card is operating correctly.

2. Power On Checks

The LED's on the comms card counting from the top indicates the following:

Ist LED Data is being received

2nd LED Data is being transmitted

3rd LED +5 volts has been generated on the comms card for the JED microprocessor

4th LED The Watchdog has reset from the JED microprocessor

5th LED Indicates the relay is on.

3. Watchdog Timer Check

With power still connected, partially remove the 16 way ribbon cable from the header. This removes the watchdog reset pulse from the JED microprocessor and the 4th LED should be on.

4. Power Off Checks

a. When the power has been removed the LEDs and the relays should be off within two or three seconds. If this does not occur this indicates the voltage fail sensor requires adjustment, repair or the comms card may require replacing.

b. While the power is off check with TCCC that communication has been lost to the site under test only.


ATTACHMENT D TO SECTION 751

(Page 2 of 6)

TRIO COMMUNICATIONS 2000

RADIO COMMUNICATION SYSTEM FOR VICROADS FREEWAY DATA STATIONS

The TC‑900DR is a UHF radio device and needs to be properly installed and commissioned in order to function reliably.

This sheet is intended as a short form checklist to ensure important tests are made and record at each site when the system is originally commissioned and for fault finding should a problem occur.

1. Installation

The TC‑900DR is a duplex device which means that it can transmit and receive simultaneously. It uses two separate frequencies which come in pairs: 929.xxxxx MHz and a low frequency 853.xxxxx MHz. The radios come in either (H)igh or (L)ow transmit versions. Examine the test label on the bottom of the TC‑900DR to determine which version the unit is. The Base Station is a TC‑900DR‑H which means that all roadside units should be TC‑900DR‑L.

Antennas are generally mounted to a vertical pole with vertical polarisation as per the licence requirement. That is, the many parallel elements on the Yagi antenna are to point in the vertical direction: the parallel bars should point towards the ground and the sky.

IMPORTANT: You will note that one of the vertical elements is a loop. This loop has a small hole on one end. Ensure that the small drain hole on one end of the dipole is pointed towards the ground so that water will drain out of the antenna.

Antennas should be mounted as high as practical and away from metal surfaces which can cause reflections. All connections must be sealed with SCOTCH 23 type (or similar) amalgamating tape (not silastic) to ensure they are waterproof.

2. Commissioning

Prior to installing a site, VicRoads must configure their database to enable the remote roadside unit so that the unit will operate upon installation of the communications system.

2.1 Check supply volts and apply power to data radio, check for power indication (Green LED is on).

2.2 Program the unit using the TC‑DFM9IP programming software and programming lead.

The following steps should be followed:

(1) Start up the software on a laptop PC.

(2) Connect serial Port 1 of the PC to Port A of the data radio using the programming lead.

(3) Select the menu 'Program a modem from a disk file'.

(4) Apply power to the TC‑900DR radio. You will now be confronted with a file menu from which to select.

(5) Select the file corresponding to the site you wish to program. You will now be presented with a program configuration page.

(6) Select 'Program Modem' located at the top centre of the screen. You will see a bar graph percentage screen depicting progress and a 'programming complete' message when complete.

(7) You can now disconnect the programming lead from Port A and plug in the actual RS‑232 cable connected the roadside unit.


ATTACHMENT D TO SECTION 751

(Page 3 of 6)

TRIO COMMUNICATIONS 2000

RADIO COMMUNICATION SYSTEM FOR VICROADS FREEWAY DATA STATIONS

2.3 If you do not get any Transmitter indication when connected to roadside unit, you can test the transmitter by connecting the PTT plug (as detailed in the following drawing) connected to Port A of the Data Radio. The 'Tx' Red LED on the front panel of the TC‑900DR should illuminate when this plug is installed to indicate RF transmission.

IMPORTANT : ONLY use this plug for very short testing periods as when this is installed, the complete system will be inhibited from operation.

2.4 Check and record for future reference RSSI (Received Signal Strength Indicator) level by connecting a multi‑meter to Pin 5 (‑ve) and Pin 9 (+ve) of Port B connector and compare with predicted results using this graph. A sound link should give a reading of approximately 2.5 Volts or higher. Any signals levels lower than this should be reported to VicRoads.

2.5 To obtain the maximum signal strength, align the antenna by pointing the antenna towards the Base Station Sites (located at the Police Academy in Mulgrave or 101 Collins Street in the city).

Note: When the antenna has been re‑aligned move away from the antenna before taking an RSSI level as readings will be effected if you are in front, behind or to the side of the antenna.

2.6 If you have a 'throughline' power meter, check and record Forward and Reflected Power.

2.7 If possible check and record TX frequency and deviation using suitable field test instrument.

2.8 To ensure that the site is receiving the Base Station reliably and with data integrity, check for solid received signal indication ('RXSIG' Yellow LED) and for continuous ('SYNC' Yellow LED) indication. If both of these lights are on solid, then there is an extremely high probability that the link is working reliably (although by further antenna alignment, it could be improved).


ATTACHMENT D TO SECTION 751

(Page 4 of 6)

TRIO COMMUNICATIONS 2000

RADIO COMMUNICATION SYSTEM FOR VICROADS FREEWAY DATA STATIONS

2.9 If the site is experiencing difficulties, the first step is to call Telstra National Operations Control Centre (NOCC) and request a site radio check which is possible from Telstra's Remote Diagnostics Monitoring capabilities which allows them to check each and every remote radio for Transmit Power, Received Signal Strength, Temperature, DC Volts and Frequency Error.

SUNLIGHT SOLAR SYSTEMS AUSTRALIA

SOLAR POWER SYSTEM FOR VICROADS FREEWAY DATA STATIONS

1. Operating Instructions

Systems will automatically begin charging the batteries during the day. Indication of system status is via five LEDs mounted on the control board of the control module. The LEDs indicate the following:

LED 1 (GREEN): SYSTEM LED - system operation

LED 2 (ORANGE): CHARGE LED - Charge mode

LED 3 (YELLOW): LOAD LED - Load mode

LED 4 (RED): BATTERY LOW LED - Battery low mode

LED 5 (RED): POLARITY LED - Wrong polarity connection

1.1 Normal Operating Mode

At all times the SYSTEM LED will flash once per second. This indicates that the system clock and program are operating as per normal. The SYSTEM LED begins to flash approximately two seconds after power up. If the SYSTEM LED cannot be made to flash then further advice should be sought to make the system fully operational.

1.2 Battery Charging Mode

During daylight hours the system will enter its battery charging mode. This is indicated by the CHARGE LED being lit. It is normal for the CHARGE LED to turn on and off during the day as the battery is fully charged.

1.3 Low Battery Warning

Should the battery become low in charge after three to four weeks of extremely poor weather, the BATTERY LOW LED will flash and the system will shut down in order to preserve the battery system from further discharge. The battery and system should return to normal after receiving a few hours of direct sunlight, however if this is not the case swap the battery and return it to the workshop for full re-charge. If necessary carry out a series of 'deep cycle' re-charging.

2. Maintenance

2.1 Solar Panels

Periodical checks should be made of the photovoltaic glass surface and wiring connections. The glass surface should be clean of any spoiling to maintain optimum system performance.

2.2 Batteries

The batteries are totally sealed and will not need electrolyte checks. The battery terminals should be periodically checked and clean of any corrosion. Should any corrosion be found on the terminals they may be coated with a sealing agent such as varnish, grease, petroleum jelly or a proprietary battery terminal spray after cleaning.

2.3 Control System

The control system is maintenance free with no adjustments being possible. Regularly check to see that the equipment is in good connection with no apparent corrosion. Make sure the enclosure is resealed after inspection.


ATTACHMENT D TO SECTION 751

(Page 6 of 6)

SUNLIGHT SOLAR SYSTEMS AUSTRALIA

SOLAR POWER SYSTEM FOR VICROADS FREEWAY DATA STATIONS

3. Testing Procedures

10 WAY CONNECTOR (CN1) 4 WAY CONNECTOR (CN2)

Pin 1: Panel Positive (+ve) Pin 1: +12 volt output

Pin 2: Battery Positive (+ve) Pin 2: GND (12 volt)

Pin 3: Panel Negative (-ve) Pin 3: GND (24 volt)

Pin 4: Battery Negative (-ve) Pin 4: +24 volt output

Pin 5: Battery Sense (-ve)

Pin 6: N/A

Pin 7: N/A

Pin 8: N/A

Pin 9: Temperature Sense Negative (-ve)

Pin 10: Temperature Sense Positive (+ve)

3.1 Checking Battery Voltage

Use a multimeter to check pins 2 and 4 of CN1, they are power supply inputs for the micro controller and load. The voltage should be above 22 volts for normal operation. The LED 1 (System Indicator) is flashing at all times at a rate of once per second.

Check Pin 5 for the battery voltage sense. If there is no voltage reading on the multimeter then an open or broken cable is assumed and the LED 4 (Low Battery Indicator) will be flashing. The LED 4 is also flashing if the battery voltage is below 22 volts and it will turn off again if the battery system is charged up to 25 volts or above.

3.2 Checking Panel Voltage

Check Pins 1 (+ve) and 3 (-ve). During daylight hours, the voltage is changing from 20 volts to 42 volts maximum dependant on the sunlight intensity.

If there is no voltage then inspect the panel cable for damage or open connection.

3.3 Checking Power Output

Check Pins 1 and 2 of the CN2 connector for the 12 volts output and Pins 3 and 4 for the 24 volts output. If the BATTERY LOW LED is flashing there will be no power output at these terminals.


ATTACHMENT E TO SECTION 751

(Page 1 of 1)

FAULT CALL-OUT PROCEDURE

TRAFFIC SIGNALS AND ON-ROAD ELECTRICAL AND COMMUNICATION DEVICES

1. A fault is reported to VicRoads or generated by the system. Where reported, TMC Officers effectively interrogate the reporter to extract information.

2. The fault is record in RAI.

3. TMC determine the fault category, 'Critical', 'Major' or 'Other'.

Note: (a) For 'Critical' faults, TMC shall action the fault in consultation with the Regional on-call officer.

(b) For 'Major' faults, TMC may notify the Contractor of the fault at any time on any day.

(c) For 'Other' faults, TMC may notify the Contractor during Normal Working hours.

4. TMC notify the Contractor of the fault and pass on available details.

5. TMC record the time of fault notification in RAI.

6. Where the Contractor is notified of the fault other than by direct communication; e.g. via paging service, email, or facsimile; the Contractor shall immediately acknowledge receipt of the fault to TMC.

7. The Contractor shall action the fault in accordance with the specified requirements.

8. The Contractor shall rectify the fault in accordance with the specified requirements.

9. For MAJOR faults, and before leaving site, the Contractor shall confirm clearance of the fault with TMC. TMC will record Contractor clearance in RAI but do not close the report.

10. The Contractor shall provide a 'Non-Routine Attendance Report' for each attendance to a site to the Superintendent in accordance with the specified requirements.

11. The Superintendent's representative will review these reports to ensure complete and appropriate information has been provided. The Superintendent's representative shall close the report in RAI when satisfied the fault has been rectified in accordance with the specified requirements.

12. Where the Superintendent's representative requires further information the Contractor shall respond within two hours of request.

13. The Superintendent's representative arranges for information from the 'Non-Routine Attendance Report' to be record in RAI generally within forty-eight hours.

COMPANY NAME: ................................................................................. TECHNICIAN ATTENDING (print name):

DATE: .................................................................................................... SIGNATURE OF TECHNICIAN ATTENDING: .

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

1

Ensure cabin ante room and computer room are clean, dried, sanitised, illuminated and secure.

All toilets and hand basins have been thoroughly cleaned and sanitised and sanitiser pellets have been replaced as required.

All toilet paper holders, hand towel dispensers and soap holders have been re-stocked. Inspect and ensure minimum supplies of two (2) rolls of toilet paper, one (1) cake of soap and one (1) roll of hand towel.

All vinyl floors swept and washed.

All rubbish bins emptied and rubbish disposed of. Bin liners replaced.

All carpeted floors cleaned. All skirting boards and benches of dusted/vacuumed.

All lighting fixtures inspected and checked that they are in good working order. Any blown globes/tubes replaced.

All inspection done for ingress of ants and presence of pests and rodents. Eradicated as required.

All inspection and repair done of any water leaks at ceiling/walls/doors.

Test and ensure telephone operates correctly.

Yes 

No* 

2

Ancillary Computer Equipment.

Logged on at SCATS Regional Computer printer terminal and:

Inspected if computer is operating with no alarm/fault status;

Inspected that Monitor and Hardcopy is operational.

Inspected print quality and replaced ribbon where necessary.

Inspected paper on the printer and ensured there is not less that 20 mm of paper available on stack.

Removed printout to prevent overflowing. Stacked printout, labelled start/finish dates and stored.

Yes 

No* 

3

Ensure all electronic cards are secure and in proper contact with connectors.

Inspected and ensured all modem and other cards are correctly aligned, connected and in good order.

Inspected and ensured all cards make proper contact with back planes and other terminals.

Yes 

No* 

4

Environmental Control System.

Inspected condition of air conditioner filter. Cleaned and/or replaced where necessary.

Inspected and ensured air conditioner settings are correct.

Inspected and ensured air conditioner and EMP operated correctly and within the specified range of 17‑24 degrees Celsius. Recorded temperature on arrival and on departure.

Inspected computer cooling fans, and ensured normal operation.

Yes 

No* 

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

5

Ensure security mechanisms are in proper working order.

Inspected and ensured mechanical door locks operated correctly and electronic Smart Lock PC interface is functional.

Inspected and ensured that the electronic security access system (Smart Lock PC interface), fixed on all external and internal access doors is fully functional.

Inspected and ensured all mechanical door locks and electric latches are in good working order (External/Internal Access Doors).

Inspected and ensured correct operation of door seals.

Inspected and ensured external security lighting fixtures are in good working order and replaced any blown globes/tubes.

Yes 

No* 

6

Ensure cabin external area is clean, neat and secure.

Record and report any advertising materials (bill posters) and graffiti.

Remove rubbish from cabin compound enclosure or within a five (5) metre perimeter area surrounding the cabin where no enclosure is defined. Report any gardening requirements outside this area.

Record and report any painting that may be required.

Made good any defects to external fixtures e.g. windows, roof, guttering and meter box.

Inspect and clean cabin roofs, spouting and grates and remov/dispose of debris from VicRoads site.

Mow grass in cabin compound enclosure or within five (5) metre perimeter area surrounding the cabin where no enclosure is defined, and dispose of waste from VicRoads site. Mowing of the grass shall be undertaken by the Contractor on a monthly basis.

Yes 

No* 

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

1

Ensure cabinets are operational, intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Remove and clean all contamination and foreign materials including water, litter, organic material, cobwebs, bills and posted advertisements, road grime, adhesives, chewing gum etc. Clean and wash down entire surfaces.

Record and report graffiti.

Inspect cabinets and ensure they are secure and waterproof, locks and hinges operational.

Repair or replace faulty locks and hinges. Repair, adjusted, re-sealed or lubricated as necessary.

Inspect and ensure that the interior of cabinet is clean and free from ingress of rodents, insects or other pests or foreign materials and applied pesticides.

Record and report program for repair or replacement of items unable to be repaired or replaced at routine service.

Yes 

No* 

2

Ensure all electronic cards are secure and in proper contact with connectors.

Inspect and ensure all modem and other cards are correctly aligned, connected and in good order.

Inspect and ensure all cards make proper contact with back planes and other terminals.

No* 

3

Ensure proper operation and display of sequence and all other functional indicators.

Observe and replace all faulty equipment, and ensure that it is fully operational.

Yes 

No* 

4

Ensure all wiring and cabling is securely connected and supported.

Inspect for loose wires on all accessible terminals, re-terminate and tighten.

Inspect and ensure all cable supports are secure and in proper working order.

Yes 

No* 

5

Ensure proper connection and housing of meter and power supply facilities.

Inspect, secure, clean and repair faulty components, and associated hardware (i.e. junction boxes, cabling, housing etc.).

Form 751.H08 ROUTINE SERVICE - TRIP INFORMATION SIGNS Page 1 of 3

SITE NAME: ......... SITE NUMBER:

COMPANY NAME: ................................................................................. TECHNICIAN ATTENDING (print name):

DATE: .................................................................................................... SIGNATURE OF TECHNICIAN ATTENDING: .

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

1

Ensure housing is intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Inspect gaskets for deterioration. Replace gaskets if broken, damaged or considered potential to fault.

Inspect and ensure all doors and locks operate freely and latches are in place. Inspect and ensure door rubber seals are in place and joined around perimeter. Remedy any noticeable gaps.

Clean faces of light sensors.

Inspect all paintwork and ensure any scratches, chips or defects are 'touched up' and match cabinet finish.

Inspect for corrosion. Repair where necessary.

Yes 

No* 

2

Ensure internal, circuit boards, wiring, lamps, connections and ancillary equipment are intact, secure and in proper working order.

Inspect and ensure all cables, connectors and sockets are neat and firmly in place.

Inspect and ensure there is no corrosion present on any cards or connectors. Inspect Printed Circuit Boards for brown or black areas on the board, around tracks, and/or components. Replace board if this is detected.

Inspect and ensure all fans on power supply unit(s) operate correctly.

Inspect and ensure any dim or failed fluorescent tubes are replaced and made operative.

Inspect and ensure inside of cabinet is clean and free from dust and debris.

Inspect and ensure fastness of all IDC connectors on alpha modules and printed circuit board panel mounts.

If applicable, check and test RCDs as per AS 3760.

Inspect and ensure that incoming mains earth is connected to earth bar in switchboard and that metalwork is earthed.

Inspect and ensure DC-to-DC converters are firmly in place. Inspect and ensure distribution terminals are mounted securely in place onto DIN rails.

Inspect and ensure all power supplies are operating and secure.

Inspect and ensure spade terminals of LED and Fibre Optic Globe power lines are firmly in place at each module and at switch mode power supply.

Inspect and ensure all cards in PC are securely in place and that IO cables are connected and firmly in place.

Inspect and ensure all terminal block data, ground and status wires are firmly in place on terminal.

Inspect and ensure labels are in place and secure.

Inspect and ensure all light dimming connectors and wires are in place. Inspect and ensure correct operation of temperature sensor.

Inspect and ensure all modules are tightly in place.

Measure, record and ensure correct operation of power supplies.

Inspect and ensure all power LED's are illuminated.

Inspect and ensure all PC power LED's are illuminated. Measure, record and ensure correct input voltages to PC.

Inspect and ensure NTU/telephone power is correct and operating.

Yes 

No* 


Form 751.H08 ROUTINE SERVICE - TRIP INFORMATION SIGNS ... continued Page 2 of 3

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

3

Ensure functionality and operation of fibre optic components.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic harnesses are well supported and are not kinked or bent.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic cables do not kink when doors close.

Inspect and ensure all (primary and secondary) fibre optic globes operate.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic lamp reflectors and mirrors are clean, unstained and unmarked. Replace as necessary.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic ferrules are in place, secure, undistorted and uncracked. Replace as necessary.

Inspect and ensure operation of 'Lamp Change Over' capability for both 'lamp failure' and peaked/dimmed operational requirements.

Inspect and ensure light box is secure, undamaged and correctly aligned.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic harnesses are securely held in place in the light box and in the optimum position for the focal characteristics of the reflector and globe.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic colour and/or heat filters are in place, undamaged and that the optimum location of light source to fibre optic harness is maintained.

Yes 

No* 

4

Ensure proper operation of cooling system.

Inspect and ensure that vents are clean.

Inspect and ensure fans operate correctly and that there is no indication of wear. Replace or repair as necessary.

Ensure thermostat is operating correctly.

Yes 

No* 

5

Ensure proper condition and operation of battery.

Inspect and ensure battery terminals are properly secure.

Inspect and ensure battery terminals and casings are clean and free of salt growth and that battery casings are not cracked or leaking.

Replace batteries if leaking or damaged.

Measure and record 12-volt battery voltages, separately and combined.

Disconnect 240v-power supply and inspect and ensure the AC fail LED illuminates.

Inspect and ensure operation of 'Battery Low' LED.

Yes 

No* 

6

Test and ensure proper operation of all flip pixels.

Blank the display then display all on. Repeat this several times using alternative wipes.

Inspect and ensure that none of the conditions noted below occurred. Repair or replace any faulty items to correct any of the conditions noted below:

Stuck pixels

Half turned pixels

Dislodged/misaligned spindles

Missing pixel dots

Misaligned modules

Inoperative LED clusters

Flashing LED clusters

Slow pixels

Incorrect column/row operation

Uneven pixel display across a module or character.

Yes 

No* 


Form 751.H08 ROUTINE SERVICE - TRIP INFORMATION SIGNS ... continued Page 3 of 3

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

7

Ensure correct operation of LED's, dimming facility and temperature sensor.

Perform routine service as per manufacturer's specification.

Yes 

No* 

8

Test and prove proper operation

Perform operational test in conjunction with VicRoads by contacting TMC and confirming all functions operate correctly.

Yes 

No* 

9

Ensure clear visibility of sign and pixels

Thoroughly clean internal face of clear facia.

Thoroughly clean all display sides of pixels.

Thoroughly clean entire external face of sign.

Yes 

No* 

* For ALL 'No' Reports provide full details of why it is 'No', and details of what action is taken.

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

1

Ensure housing is intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Inspect gaskets for deterioration. Replace gaskets if broken or damaged or considered potential to fault.

Inspect and ensure all doors and locks operate freely and latches are in place. Inspect and ensure door rubber seals are in place and joined around perimeter. Remedy any noticeable gaps. Inspect and ensure inside of cabinet is clean and free from dust and debris.

Clean faces of light sensors.

Inspect all paintwork and ensure any scratches, chips or defects are 'touched up' and match cabinet finish.

Inspect and repair any corrosion spots.

Inspect and ensure radio antenna is securely in place and properly connected. Repair or replace if necessary.

Yes 

No* 

2

Ensure internals, circuit boards, wiring, lamps, connections and ancillary equipment are intact, secure and in proper working order

Inspect and ensure all cables and connectors are in good condition, secure and firmly in place.

Inspect and ensure there is no corrosion present on any cards or connectors.

Inspect painted circuit boards for brown or black areas on the board, around tracks, and/or components. Replace board if this is detected.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic harnesses are well supported and are not kinked or bent.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic cables do not kink when doors close.

Inspect and ensure all (primary and secondary) fibre optic globes operate.

Inspect and ensure fibre optic lamp reflectors and mirrors are clean, unstained and unmarked. Replace as necessary.

Inspect and ensure all fibre optic ferrules are in place, secure, undistorted and uncracked. Replace as necessary.

Inspect and ensure operation of 'Lamp Change Over' capability for both 'lamp failure' and peaked/dimmed operational requirements.

Inspect and ensure all connectors are firmly in sockets and all wires are firmly in each connector.

Inspect all data and power cables. Inspect and ensure all ribbon cables are secure to channels and secure all slack cables.

Inspect and ensure that incoming mains earth is connected to earth bar in switchboard and that metalwork is earthed.

Inspect and ensure spade terminals of Fibre Optic Globe power lines are firmly in place at each module and at power supply.

Inspect and ensure labels are in place. Inspect and ensure internal paintwork is free of defects. Touch up if necessary.

Inspect and ensure all light dimming connectors and wires are in place.

Inspect and ensure proper operation of radio.

Inspect and ensure radio and that all communication connections are secure, clean and free of corrosion.

Yes 

No* 

Inspect and ensure vents are clean and clear.

4

Test and ensure proper operation of all pixels.

Missing or inoperative pixel dots

Dim pixels

Dislodged or misaligned pixels

Misaligned modules

ITEM

DESCRIPTION

(on departure)

THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT BE LIMITED TO:

REPORT

1

Ensure proper operation and display of vehicle detection systems.

Inspect and ensure that all vehicle detection systems and associated functional indicators are operational, correctly tuned and connected in accordance with the operation design. This shall include identification of each individual detection functional indicator and verification that operation corresponds with activation of its relevant detection loop. Retune or replace as necessary.

Inspect vehicle detector loops and feeders, correct and report defects (including exposed cables).

Check earth connection and make sure it has the required impedance.

Yes 

No* 

2

Ensure cabinets are intact, secure, clean and undamaged.

Remove and clean all contamination and foreign materials including water, litter, organic material, cobwebs, road grime, adhesives, chewing gum, sharps etc. Clean and wash down entire surfaces.

Record, report and remove graffiti as per Clause 751.C08.

Inspect that cabinets are secure and waterproof, locks and hinges operational.

Repair, adjust re-seal or lubricate as necessary.

Inspect and ensure that the interior of cabinet is clean and free from ingress of rodents, insects or other pests or foreign materials and apply pesticides.

Record and report program for repair or replacement of items unable to be repaired or replaced at routine service.

Yes 

No* 

3

Ensure all electronic cards are secure and in proper contact with connectors.

Inspect and ensure all modem and other cards are correctly aligned, connected and in good order.

Inspect and ensure all cards make proper contact with back planes and other terminals.

Yes 

No* 

4

Ensure proper connection and housing of meter and power supply facilities.

Inspect, secure, clean and repair faulty components, and associated hardware (i.e. junction boxes, cabling, housing etc.).

Inspect housing of meter and power supply facilities; arrange power authority to repair if required.

If applicable check and test RCDs as per AS 3760.

Inspect and ensure optimum operation of the solar charge control module (where installed). Arrange vegetation trimming to keep solar panel uncovered.

Inspect and ensure optimum operation and integrity of solar panels and batteries; (where installed).

Inspect and ensure batteries maintain charge sufficient for continuous operation 24 hours, 7 days a week.

Yes 

No* 
